voice_to_text: Oh, it's because they didn't have a fan fiction phase. They did not have a fan fiction phase. Or even worse, they did have fan fictions that got really popular. And they assumed because they were popular as fan fictions, that means that one to one, as a published work, they would be seen and critiqued just as good. Which, if El James and I think the book is called after, are any examples. That's not true. The rules of writing fanfiction are very different than the rules of writing independent stories. But also, fanfiction is a space where you can anonymously, unless you make yourself known on other platforms or give yourself a face, you can flex your creative muscles. You can write really dark, messed up stuff. You can write really cute stuff. You can gauge people's reactions and be peered reviewed. And peer review is very important when you are going to publish something that is meant to be read by your peers. And to be able to do that in a space where you have complete anonymity, to fail and try again is so critically important to creative writing. Because, let's be honest, in a lot of English classes, you're not being graded on your creativity. You're being graded on your ability to follow a format, your technical process, and how well you're able to articulate your points. In creative writing classes, you are stifled by the amount of other students in your class as well. As your teacher, my creative writing room was incredibly stifled. We only had 12 kids. We all came from very different walks of life, and our teacher was super homophobic and limited what we could write about. I didn't really start growing and learning as a writer until I got on Fanfiction Net. I had been writing stories since I was, like, 8 years old, but when I was 15, I published my first work, and that's where I really started to progress in my writing capability. People told me things. People reminded me of things. People said, hey, if you were this, it might flow better. Editing was something I really didn't understand, and thankfully, there were people in my comments being like, hey, you spelled this wrong. That sort of feedback made me, you know, edit things. It made me rethink format. It made me rethink scenario. Through reading fanfiction, I would find authors who wrote beautifully, and I mimicked that style of writing. I took pieces of different artisans and made my own style, and I use that to write my own published books. Even with my own published books, because of this new area of peer review that I'm in, I have drastically changed my writing. From my first book, branches to my new book, Give Fangs a chance, there was a very noticeable jump in quality, not just on my writing skills, but also the art books I made for each book. A lot of The authors that are publishing these trite trophy fanfiction, feely novels are a product of never doing thorough peer review. I was writing fan fiction for 10 years before I then actually published my first book. And I can tell you in no uncertain terms, that drastically helped me.

voice_to_text: This might honestly be game over for Hollywood. A new AI streaming services launched where you can create the shows. Let me tell you about it. Revealed today by The Hollywood Reporter. We got revealed of a new streaming service from a company named fable. It says here that users will be able to watch AI generated series, create their own content, complete with the ability to control dialogue, characters and shot types, among other controls. This is sadly the very future on where we're headed for movies and TV shows. A future where you come home after a long day, you turn on your TV, and you tell your streaming service, I'd like a superhero movie where Batman and Superman fall in love and fight Spider Man. Make it. And right now, the streaming service is only able to do animated shows. No live action stuff. And it probably doesn't even look all that great. But this is always the least impressive. It'll look tomorrow. It's gonna get better. And two, three, five years from now, it's going to rival our regular movies and TV shows. The other part that sucks about this, the older generation like me, where this is new, we don't like this. We hate this idea. May ummm May this close nearly put me into a reading slump let's get into it I read nine books in the month of may let's wrap it up so the first book I read this month was asked for Andrea by Noelle. W Ihli we are following three girls that have been 💀 by a serial 🔪  and we're watching them come together to get justice um I really did enjoy this this felt very original nothing that I've read before my only criticism would be that I wish the girls had come together sooner I had to wait until like the 70% Mark for all three of the girls to finally meet up and without going into too much detail the wife of the douchebag in this book I literally CANT with her like I cannot stand her The Family Experiment by John Marrs I have said this before I'm gonna say it now and I'm gonna keep saying it this man is the king of speculative fiction in this book we are following a plethora of couples who are on a reality TV show and they have basically raised a child or a virtual child from scratch and the prize at the end of the show is they either get to keep their virtual child or they can risk it all and basically have a real baby in the real world now obviously this is not gonna be a John Mars book without major major drama and secrets and that is exactly what he delivered if I have to give this book one criticism it would be the excessive amount of characters in this book it did take me a hot minute to be like who's who and what's your story but eventually I did get the hang of it and have an amazing time the trap by Catherine Ryan Howard in this book we are following a woman named Lucy who in the dead of night is trying to get a lift from a serial 🔪 who she believes took her sister Nikki I mean what is there not to love the book started off so strong and then literally went nowhere and I will give this book props on the twist It was very different and unique but having to go through all that FAFF beforehand to get to that twist it just wasn't worth it for me so unfortunately this was yeah it was a major flop home is where the bodies are by Geneva Rose um I'm just gonna put out there this book was rude AF um there's no reason why I should be guessing the twist of a book within the first 20 to 25 pages okay at this point it felt like Geneva wrote the twist for us and wanted us to continue going through the pages like oh my god I wonder who did it  are you being so for real? like look at this gorgeous cover I was so excited to read this but the pages within was absolutely  meh um if you wasn't able to guess the twist…  yeah  missing  Woman by Kellye Garrett so you and your boo have decided to go out on a romantic getaway and on the last day of the getaway you wake up in the morning walk down and see that there is a woman unalived in the foyer um and your man's nowhere to be seen either I beg your finest pardon that's exactly what happens to Bree in this book I really really enjoyed this I did um enjoy Bree's character I really enjoyed the social commentary on just how hard it is for us women to survive in today's society and the social media commentary as well on just how like internet sluice can mess up investigations felt very accurate what I didn't like was that the book was very slow pace some of the metaphors that were used in a book was borderline cringe for my old ass and I'm a bit unsure about how I feel about the ending but overall it was a good solid thriller the one that got away with Shmada by Trish Lundy we are following Lauren who has just started a new school and the boy that she's dating him and his brother in the town are basically known as shmurderers who got away with a 💀 their ex girlfriends and for some reason Lauren decides that she wants to become a sleuth and find out what really happened and okay this book was okay if you really enjoy YA thrillers this is definitely for you it definitely read like a YA book um I semi guess the twist in the book um the first 45% I was absolutely bored snooze fest um I did not care for any of their characters and the ending was so abrupt and lackluster I… yeah  The Colour Purple by Alice Walker if you have seen the movie I would still highly highly highly recommend that you read the book because I'm always a believer that the book is better than the movie from the beginning all the way to the end of this book this had me by the ropes the main character Sally will forever have my heart I just could not get enough there was so many things in this book that I could resonate with and I just can't wait to read it again so I can annotate it and I'm calling it now that I definitely feel like this is gonna be a part of my top 10 of 2024  darling girls by Sally Hepworth this is my first by this author and it's definitely not gonna be my last I really did enjoy this one um I would not say it's a thriller I probably say it's more of like a suspensful domestic like family domestic kind of book um I enjoyed the free POV from the women in this and getting a better understanding of what it's like to be fostered honestly that it this pictures had me so engrossed um the negatives and this is more of a personal issue you know how I feel about my slow burns I do not like slow burn books but I do understand why it was needed for this one and there was just portions of this book that did feel a bit scattered but overall I cannot wait to read more from this author and then finally I read you know what you did by K.T Nguyen we are following Annie Shaw who has a perfect life right up until her war refugee mum passes away and it ends up unlocking her compulsive OCD and then everything just goes from zero to 100 one of the women that she works with ends up disappearing and the police think that Annie has something to do with it and then the next minute Annie is waking up in a hotel room naked with a lifeless body next to her there was a lot going on in this book I really did enjoy it um I felt very much like claustrophobic and itchy vibes this is definitely more character driven than plot um Annie's backstory and just understanding more about how generational trauma exists was very very interesting to read but unfortunately it was just so long it was longer than it needed to be and the ending was so over the top that it just felt like it gone from literary fiction to popcorn thriller and I was just a bit confused by that but overall it was a very good solid thriller  and thank you so much to Penguin Random House for sending me a gifted copy of this book

What do we actually know about Shakespeare??
voice_to_text: What do we actually know about Shakespeare? He was a businessman, a producer, and an actor. He evaded taxes twice. He had restraining orders taken out against him by multiple business associates. He hoarded grain during a famine and he hiked up the price of it for his neighbors and he was fine for that. He allegedly wrote 38 plays all by himself while having a full time job as an actor. Although every other playwright at the time collaborated with others, he never left the country. Although his plays are about Italy and Denmark and Egypt, and they use details that weren't available in guidebooks at the time. He didn't play an instrument, although Shakespearean plays have more than 3,000 specific references to music. He didn't attend university and maybe not even grammar school, and he's usually thought of a self taught. But he died without owning a single book to his name. He wasn't buried in Poet's Corner, although far less notable writers were. And at the time of his death, he was not lauded by any other playwrights or poets. What do we not have any record of about Shakespeare? That he actually wrote the plays. On the other hand, what do we know about Amelia Basano? She was Italian. Her family were the court musicians to Henry VIII and Queen Elizabeth the first. They were recorder players for the court. She was Jewish, as was the rest of her family, and they had to hide their faith. When she was seven years old, she was given to the Countess of Kent as a ward and was given a classical and legal education. When the countess wound up getting married when Emilio was 12, she was living with her brother, Peregrin Barty, who was a baron and who happened to be the ambassador to Denmark at the time. He did do a diplomatic mission then, and either would have gone with him or would have heard all about it. At age 13, she became the mistress to the Lord Chamberlain of England. He was 56 years old. He was responsible for all theater in England at the time. Every single play crossed his desk to be censored, and he would decide what played where and what was allowed to play and what wasn't allowed to play. And absolutely, at the time, Amelia would have met all the people that were in the theater world because the Lord Chamberlain worked with him. After 10 years, this is mistress. She got pregnant and she was kicked out of his house. She was made to marry her wastral of a cousin, who wound up basically going through all of her money. So she now had a kid and a family to support, and she needed money to do it in her 40s. In 1611, she became the first published female poet in all of England, which is a huge accomplishment in her own right. But people don't just show up and Get their work published when they're 40 years old. If they haven't been writing before. Unless, of course, she was writing before, and she was doing it under someone else's name.

They’re not even good books
voice_to_text: You know, for club whose barrier to entry is just having a library card and a little bit of free time, Book Talk has got to be one of the least hospitable places on the entire internet. It's the I eel waste of online communities. Now, obviously, I don't mean all of you, which is a disclaimer I have to add, since some of you have the media literacy of a smoked walnut. But I do mean a very loud, very vocal some of you. And I'm not just talking about just towards me. A couple days ago, I made a video in which I made a series of jokes about how you all read very quickly and I read very slowly. I called you all the reincarnation of Dewey Decimal. I didn't think anybody would watch that video and come to the conclusion that I actually believed you were lying about how many books you've read. It fell flat. That's fine. I make jokes on the internet almost every single day. Not all of them are going to be winners. But we can't have an enemies to lovers romance if you don't tag me in the videos you make hating on me. I wonder why you neglected to do that. I think I know. It's because you're mean people and you wanna turn book talk into the Mean Girls table of the internet. I came to this conclusion several months ago when I started to see people's reactions to The Fay Ball. Remember that? There's a bunch of people in costume having fun, and you all treated it like it was the worst thing to happen to books since the burning of the library of Alexandria. What kind of a person sees other people having fun and thinks to themselves, I hate that, and I need to tell the world exactly how much I. I hate that! Imagine if you saved that energy for actual atrocities, not imagined ones. Imagine what the world would look like. When I first started to see these videos, I thought you all were joking. I thought you were doing an amarantha impression. Turns out you're just amarantha. Add that to the long list of things that booktok hates seemingly just because they're fun. Cosplay liking a series that's become too popular. Liking a character not liking a character. Liking a character but not enough leaving thirsty comments and videos about a romanticy series. There are books about impossibly beautiful immortal Fae. They're not James Joyce fan theories. I made a video in which I theorized that Rhysand was actually the bad guy this entire time. Some people treated it like he was a real person and I was confessing to have framed him for a crime. Now look, it's not my community, you can do whatever you want with it. I just wanted book recommendations. I didn't realize I was getting them from Sauron himself. But I think if you set both the Kindle and your phone down for 15 minutes and engaged in a little self reflection. You will come to learn, as I have, that you are not Alan Galatinius. You are Matron Blackbeek, viciously bullying and putting down anyone who steps outside your arbitrary bubble of approval. Having fun is easy when you're a good person. And once other people start to learn that about you, I wonder how long you'll have a community.

voice_to_text: there's a guy who only writes books that  will be adapted into movies because nobody buys books anymore and it's made him very successful his name is Ben Mezrich and it's definitely movies  that you've seen I found out about this listening to  the FilmCast Pod which you should definitely check out and I looked into it Ben Mezrich graduates from college and  tells his parents he's gonna be a writer which they're none too pleased about but they say hey look we'll give you a year if it doesn't work you're going to law school in that year he writes nine novels none of them get published but the editor takes pity on him  and tells him look read some John Grisham do that so he starts writing  a bunch of thrillers all of which get published but none of which sell until he happens to run into  six MIT students who have been going to Vegas and  hustling the casinos so he writes a non fiction book about it  called Bringing Down the House while he's writing the treatment he also writes an article about  it for Wires after the articles published he gets a call in the middle of the night  from Kevin Spacey and he even says in the interview back then that was a way better phone  call than it would be today all of a sudden his book becomes the movie 21 and  sells all kinds of copies so now his whole thing is to do these  non fiction things and he gets all kinds of emails and  pitches about things to write about he gets an email that says my best friend founded Facebook and  nobody knows who he is it's Eduardo Savrin he talks to him he finds the Winklevoss twins  and talks to them he finds Sean Parker and all of a sudden  he's writing the treatment and the treatment gets  leaked to Gawker he's gonna call his book  The Accidental Billionaires lucky for him Aaron Sorkin and David Fincher see the  treatment in Gawker and decide to make the movie and it becomes the Social Network ever since then that has become Ben Mezrich’s  business model he'll come up with an idea write a 10 page treatment and shop it around Hollywood if he can't option it for a movie he won't write the book this is what he does every time he wrote a book called  The Antisocial Network that became  the movie Dumb Money he’s sold like 25 of these things not all of which actually get  made into movies but he sells the rights it might not be a very romantic  approach to literature but it's smart because according to Elle Griffin in an article she wrote  for the Elysian Nobody Buys Books Anymore she talks about how in 2022 Penguin Random House wanted to buy  Simon and Schuster but the department of justice blocked  the sale due to a monopoly but as part of that all the big publishers had to release  their figures and it turns out the big publishers spend almost all of  their money on celebrity book deals like with Britney Spears and most of their sales come from those or legacy bestseller reprints like  Lord of the Rings or children's books 96% of newly published books sell less  than 1,000 copies I made the video the other day about how movie theaters are really  struggling right now so if you're like me and you wanna  either make movies or write books things are looking good you should do it

voice_to_text: okay we are almost at our two month Mark so I just wanted to give you guys a quick update on B Gate so if you remember two months ago we opened our daughter's wall and we found over 65,000 bees inside first two extractions we were able to get 25,000 and 25,000 and yes for everybody asking it's actually weighed in this B box here so they weigh it and they can tell how many are in the B box so we got 25,000 then we got 25,000 that's my adorable daughter sailor looking at it because these were all in her bedroom and as you can see we waited two days to see what would shake out we ended up having thousands of bees in her room that came out of that plastic because I found out that they can eat through the plastic so we had to get the beekeeper to come back three more days and then we looked and I realize that there are even more bees in there because there's something called robber bees that come in and they try to clean up all the honeycomb we had over 100 pounds of honeycomb that was taken out and that's me kind of in disbelief because we have honey everywhere so Curtis Pkeeper came out he looks through his Thermal cam and he realized that oh my gosh there's more bees so he starts to do an investigation to make sure we haven't missed any spots so he came back out for the fifth time and look oh there's another 5,000 bees so right now we're waiting and we're still going through it it's been two months and we have over 65,000 removed

video_description: Sweet summer baby infant 😭 #fypage #grrm #windsofwinter #gameofthrones #asoiaf
voice_to_text: Where is winds of winter? How has a professional author not delivered this book in almost 13 years? Now, I'm gonna tell you. I'm gonna tell you right now what the hell happened. First off, if you haven't seen this YouTube video by Preston Jacobs, I think this is the most correct and zero accounting of what happened. But people have all sorts of theories, and I think they're mostly wrong. A lot of people have this idea of, oh, the any of game of Thrones actually was his real ending, and he realized everyone hated it, so now he had to, like, scrap and start over. This is dead wrong, dude. Anyone who's read the books know that David and Dan stopped adapting the books after season 4. Unless you think that all the characters that George introduced in the last two books that are book only, he just implemented for no reason, realize that the the book in the show endings cannot be the same. It's not possible. So, no, he never started over. He hasn't been riding The Winds of winter and A dream of spring at the same time. I'm sorry. The only reason he hasn't finished winds of winter is because literally, he hasn't been riding it. He finished A dance with Dragons. He had a compromise and cut out like a few hundred pages out of the end of that. But that he was gonna carry over to wins a winner. It means every Time he did an interview that few years after Dance With Dragon, saying, oh, I have a few hundred pages done on wins the winner. It's like, yeah, you always had that done. You haven't written anything new. Then, as you know, he started work on fire and blood, and then that came out in 2017. So at this point, you could argue he hadn't written anything on the winter winner. 2019, he said, the next summer, I will have it in hand. I have no idea why he thought he could do that. Obviously he didn't even get close. COVID hit. This is when we know he actually wrote. This is when he wrote the most, when he was in self isolation. No house the Dragon, no shows, no nothing but the book. After that happened, he went back with HBO, House the Dragon, all these shows, and he's busier than ever. So honestly, unless another pandemic happens, I don't know if we'll ever get win the winner.

video_description: Short book recs please! #booktok
How do you come up with ideas for new content?  #booktok #writersoftiktok #reader #authorsoftiktok #readersoftiktok
voice_to_text: I post content every single day and one of the things that I struggle with is coming up with ideas for new videos, new content. So I thought I'd share some of the things that I do to help me keep turning out a video every single day. One thing that I do to come up with ideas is Google. I have googled bookish questions and got a massive list of questions that I can answer in my own videos and sometimes those questions inspire me to think about other things. I also maintain a Google Sheet on my phone so that when I get a sudden idea for a video, I can just add it to the spreadsheet, save it, and look at it later. Another thing that I do is I bookmark videos that I find that either have a sound I wanna use or a question that I wanna answer so that I can look back on them later when I need ideas. Overall, I just try to get inspired by what other people are doing and still make things original. What do you do when you have content creation block?

video_description: Replying to @kingdom_of_flames heres what I do! alternately, you can combine chapters if chapter length is what's getting you down #writing #writingadvice #writertok #writingtips #howtowriteabook
voice_to_text: what if your book is too short and you want to make it longer I am also an underwriter so here's how I flush out my drafts first and most importantly I make sure my pacing isn't too fast that I'm leaving room for emotions to be felt in process so instead of barreling from plot point to plot point I give my characters a chance to sit in their feelings and to really like get into those emotions and grapple with them second I'll make sure that all my minor characters have minor character arcs like what are their hopes and dreams and how can I flesh those out in a cool and interesting way how do they change throughout the story then I look to go and add more nuance to my themes by giving every character a differing point of view on that theme and have them express in the meaningful way but let's say you want a more structural level edit usually then for me I need to add more obstacles between the character and their goal and usually that means invoking a subplot that involves one of those minor character arcs that I talked about earlier this can also mean turning a victory into a failure and having that failure set them back you can always add obstacles or add failure to increase that time and you give yourself more room to explore all your cool themes and plotlines hope that helps

video_description: 🌟Explore the untold stories of school trauma and the dyslexic dilemma. Many dyslexics experience similar challenges during school that can echo into adulthood, often shaping their paths in unexpected ways. This video sheds light on these experiences, offering hope and strategies for thriving despite past struggles. Join us to understand how embracing neurodiversity can unlock your true potential and propel you toward success.🌟 #DyslexiaAwareness #UnmaskDyslexia #SchoolTrauma #Neurodiversity #Empowerment #EducationalSupport #DyslexicStrengths #OvercomeChallenges #ThriveWithDyslexia #Neurodivergent #SelfCare #WorkLifeBalance #MentalHealth #DyslexiaSupport #TransformChallenges #ThriveWithDyslexia #InclusiveEducation #InvisibleStruggles #Empowerment #UnderstandingDyslexia #NeurodiverseStrengths #Educate #Advocate #SupportDyslexia #BeBrave #NeurodiversityAcceptance #DyslexiaStrengths #LifeWithDyslexia #DyslexicBrains #EmbraceDifferences #DyslexiaSupport #BeyondLabels #NeurodiverseWorld #ChangePerceptions #UnmaskDyslexia #BrainWiring, #InclusiveWorkplace, #Empowerment, #MentalHealthAwareness, #UniqueMinds, #Neuroversal, #StrengthInDifferences #dyslexicdilemma #schooltrauma #entrepreneurs #ofenders #dyslexicstats
voice_to_text: If you're masking your dyslexia at work for fear of being treated differently by your colleagues, listen up. What I'm about to say may sound very familiar. Did you struggle with reading at school? Did the mere thought of reading allowed make your heart race with the fear of making a public mistake? Perhaps you counted paragraphs ahead, trying to practice the right one in advance, yet still found yourself stumbling. Ironically, without the pressure of an audience, you would have struggled far less. Did you dread timed tests? No matter how well you prepared, the ticking clock would send you into a panic, preventing you from performing to your true potential. And all too often, your teacher might have labeled you as careless or lazy. Do you recall understanding concepts and formulas yet still receiving poor marks? It was as if your ability to recall facts on demand simply vanished. At the worst times, it seemed like your brain would just freeze. When it came to writing, you can find yourself to simple words you could spell, even though your ideas were complex. You noticed you made far more mistakes than usual. When copying from the board and accurately transcribing dictations seem nearly impossible, you were aware that these skills did not fairly represent your true abilities. Your coping mechanisms often go unnoticed, but they are constantly in use today. We refer to this as masking. The conscious or unconscious suppression or modification of your natural behaviours, responses and Characteristics to conform to societal norms. We dyslexics do it so well that we almost don't notice it ourselves. Many of us with dyslexia share a common schooling experience that profoundly shapes our adult perspectives. The repeated trauma of being told we weren't trying hard enough despite our extra efforts has driven many of us to extremes. This includes a fierce determination to excel at work, a burning desire to succeed, or preoccupation with our shortcomings rather than our strengths. It's therefore no surprise that between 20% and 40% of successful entrepreneurs are dyslexic and 40% to sixty percent of offenders are too. Indeed, we stand at a critical dyslexic fork in the road. This isn't the whole story of dyslexia, but if these experiences resonate with you, you might be among the 17% of people globally who are dyslexic. The good news recognising your neurodiversity is the first step towards identifying your strengths, establishing boundaries and seeking the accommodations you need to thrive. Don't let dyslexia limit you. Celebrate it. Leverage your unique abilities and take control of your future. You have the intelligence, skill and strength to shape your destiny. Ready to reclaim your power? Start now by seeking support, whether through professional guidance or a community that understands. Remember, you're not alone. Follow for more insights like share or tag someone who would appreciate this message. Let's learn from each other and nurture a healthy relationship with our inner dyslexic. Your journey towards a more balance life Starts right here, right now.

video_description: Replying to @scorpiowarrior652 An English degree or an MFA isn’t going to magically make you publishable, but learning isn’t going to hold you back, either. #writerscommunity #publishing #writingtips #editors #writersoftiktok #authorsoftiktok #writing
voice_to_text: how much does a degree in English actually help you become an author my name is Gina I am an author editor publishing professionally help you make your writing better it doesn't other than the fact that like learning is always good for you there's nothing wrong with an English degree it's not gonna hurt you it's not gonna hold you back but it is not going to be the magic arrow in your quiver of skills that makes you suddenly totally and completely ready to be a published author learning is always going to be good for you going to college if you can afford it and without debt it is a net positive I believe I again I don't think that the diminishing returns of a college degree specifically are necessarily worth all of the debt that's the decision you have to make for yourself getting an English degree is not going to give you a leg up into this industry look closely at the bio section of your favourite authors or of the agents that you are querying or even the editors who are working at publishing houses and how few of them actually have English degrees many of them have degrees from very elite universities but they have them in other things many published authors do have college degrees it is a career path that requires a lot of time and investment ahead of time before you make any money and so it falls to people who have more privilege in their pockets and so they tend to be much more educated than the average but again not as many of them have English degrees as you might think there are certainly plenty of English degrees floating around people who loved reading books are going to try their hand at writing one at some point so yeah there's a bunch of English degrees floating around but it is not because of their English degree that they are successful English degree can give them some tools but those tools can be Learned in other ways as well most people are successful because they spent time honing their craft they spent time putting pen to paper and being writers and becoming good at the thing that they love so much you can do that with an English degree in your back pocket you can do that with an accounting degree or no degree at all the ability to sit and learn and the ability to internalize feedback is something that anybody can pick up advice is doubly important at the master's level and MFA is great if you can afford to do it without any debt it is very unlikely to financially pay off though that will give you a lot of skills that you can use in becoming a published author or an editor or somebody who works at a publishing house but I took a class from Melanie Jacobson who has a very very successful self publishing career who after having a fairly successful traditional publishing career and she taught a class on what her MFA taught her and how you can give yourself an MFA at home for free completely and the answer was read critically a lot for a long time you can pick up the skills on how to read critically you can pick up the skills on how to write and self edit you can do all of this it takes time it takes effort and it's not going to be fast but neither is an MFA neither is a bachelor's degree you're going to have to put the time in one way or the other if you can do school without incurring a lot of debt and that's the thing that's going to give you the skills that you need and you want somebody at your side helping guide you through that process school's not a bad way to do that but it's not a magic bullet

video_description: Each one of these has a story and meaning thats different for each person and I think thats my favorite part of this collection #pridecollection #pridemonth #pridetshirt #lgbtqia #heatpressbusiness
voice_to_text: hey you have to promote that thing that you're proud of or else no one will ever find it or hear about fine here we go my name is Michelle Frost I'm the owner of East Coast Tags and we make colorless pride apparel why do we do this because we noticed there was a hole in the market for people in the LGBTQIA+ community that does not always want to wear an associated flag on their garments whether that be for safety or style there's a whole bunch of different reasons but what we also found out which is really really really cool is that one it's great for allies because then they get to rock whatever association that they want to as well and then two we found out that people look at the designs first don't always understand the meaning but whoever they are interacting with gets to then fill them in on the meaning which is cool cause then you're in a conversation that you otherwise wouldn't have been because a roadblock would have been set up mentally or emotionally or whatever because you saw a LGBTQ related flag but in this case you didn't so now you get to talk about things like being who you needed back then for me this was just a adult lesbian that was just living their life that wasn't completely consumed with their identity because they were growing up in a religious household and then I saw that and an English teacher and thought oh my god this doesn't have to be all who I am and who I'm thinking about I can just live and I can just be and it does actually get better as cliche as that sounds so that's one version for your phobias a little bit of the exception because it's somewhat self explanatory but you'd be surprised how many people don't get this and then they're in that conversation but they're in it in a cool way because people love this style art timing is everything whether that's coming out to your family or to your friends you know you have to decide when it's safe for you and with whom so it's just a reminder of yeah you gotta be careful out there so I added the just wait and see because like I said before it does get better progress isn't always pretty it sure shit isn't when it came to my family I went in the closet I went out the closet I went in the closet I went out the closet for many different reasons that was not pretty but it was still progress and we're landed where we are now and I'm super happy for the journey that I've been through for those who are sick of it little bit more on the aggressive side but I think you get it you get it and of course there's more listed on our website you know where to find that

video_description: Replying to @Eve i say this with LOVE 🫶🏾 #booktok #booktokcommunity #blackbooktok #bookishhumor #bookishthoughts
voice_to_text: Hey, Eve, um, so you said, can we talk about all the books being read? The amount of books being read? Um, no, I don't wanna talk about that. You know why? Because the amount of books that somebody else is reading in their leisure time is there business. And me personally, I don't mind other people's business. Now, you also said that speed readers can't possibly be having the same experience as non speed readers. And I just find it funny how you would want to come on my post and talk about me, because I'm somebody who reads very fast. Right? I didn't take offense to it. I'm just kidding. But we can't talk about that. But i'mma reverse it back to you and ask you and everybody else who feels like people who read fast are experiencing the book the same way. If I read Johnny had five apples yesterday in five seconds, and you read Johnny had five apples yesterday in two days, did we not both come to the same conclusion? That Johnny had five fucking apples yesterday? Yes or no? Exactly. Same fucking thing. The speed of which someone reads does not dictate the experience of the book. We are reading the exact same thing. You don't need to read slow to be able to enjoy something. And this is not a race. Who cares if somebody reads a book in a day or in fucking 10 days? That's their business. And quite frankly, I'mma hold your hand when I say this. We don't mind other people's business over here. You have a wonderful night.

I am in 1,000% agreement that Jason Grace is one of the dirtiest done characters in the riot inverse and that his story was cut criminally short. But I disagree with the notion that it was because his memories were not fully returned to him. Now, don't get me wrong, a fully realized Jason Grace, the son of Jupiter, the predator of New Rome, would have been next level. Peak heroes of Olympus, Peak Trials of Apollo, but it would not have necessarily fixed his character. Because for Percy Jackson, resolving his amnesia was 100% necessary, absolutely non negotiable for his character and the story. Which is why he had to remember Annabeth whether Hera let him or or not. Because he had to know he had a life before this, a life worth returning to otherwise. Fatal flaws. Loyalty. He would not have turned on the Romans. Jason, however, he never felt at home at Camp Jupiter. We know this from a young age. The time he was a child, he had duty and expectations and responsibilities thrust upon him. He needed to be free, unburdened by all of that, to properly explore and embrace camp half blood and be the bridge that Hera needed him to be.

as a music teacher and someone who's been involved in the production education and audition side of children's musical theater I have some opinions about Kim Kardashian's kid performing Simba at the Hollywood Bowl before I say anything else I wanna be clear I do not blame northwest this child had nothing to do with this decision and she may have been dragged through this process all the way through we all know that this is her parents fault and it is the casting director's fault Nepo babies and stunt casting is nothing new in the entertainment industry but I think as far as musical theater goes especially for children we're talking about a different animal certain things need to be held to a higher standard for a few reasons her parents and that casting director threw her to the wolves without any training at all and they knew that they knew that this child had no vocal training no stage training no musical theater training and they made the decision to put her on stage anyway as far as the casting director goes I have to say how dare they make this decision whether it was a stunt cast or not that decision affected every other singer in that performance as well you're talking about ensemble casting everyone has to be on point which is why the audition process is so important in musical theater it's not that we don't want people that already have name recognition on the stage but when you put someone on stage that doesn't know what they're doing can't keep a steady beat can't sing in tune that affects the entire ensemble I wouldn't necessarily have so much of an issue with that if this ensemble were entirely adults we're talking about something that had more than one child in the cast if you have the lead singer going up there and singing garbage it is gonna throw off every single other kid on stage we see Nepo babies less in musical theater because it takes a certain level of training to do what you need to do on stage to be successful it's really hard to skirt by because there are certain vocal qualities that you have to meet there are certain techniques that you have to use on stage that are pretty standard across the board regardless of what show you're talking about or what vocal style you use popular music it's something that you can maybe get away with because you have a unique sound or my problem with Kim Kardashian and the producers of the show is that they never gave that child a chance to get to that level I know that there were dozens of kids that auditioned to perform that number and perform Simba it's not necessarily that the right kid gets that role every single time because there's always gonna be some level of subjectivity but there has to be a level of credibility to the audition process in musical theater in order for a child to be ultimately successful in musical theater they have to start training as early as possible on stage presence dancing singing voice technique and when you throw a child into an audition and they see that the kid that didn't even audition that didn't even sing the number got the role it kills all incentive for them to ever try that process again those children leave believing that there's no point in trying anymore and I have a huge problem with that it's going to affect the kids didn't get that part it's also going to affect northwest he is going to grow up believing that she doesn't have to put in that level of work to be successful at musical theater and I feel sorry for her when she gets to be a few years older and she may decide she wants to pursue the stage on Broadway she may not have the chops for it and I don't think at that point she's gonna get the parts that she wants and she's gonna be very confused about why that's not happening for her yes they're stunt casting but stunt casting usually happens with adults even a stunt cast happens when that person is already famous for performing and being on stage whether or not they're a singer or not that kind of plays into it and it's obvious that this child has never had any stage training at all I'm pissed at her parents I'm pissed at Kim Kardashian and everyone else involved in that camp for not even taking a second thought to think that maybe that child wanted to be in music lessons maybe she wanted a vocal coach maybe she wanted to be better than that performance but they didn't take one second to think about the fact that that could even be a possibility they have all the money in the world and they don't wanna pay one red cent to hire somebody to see where their baby can go they took the shortcut that child will suffer in the end because of it she gonna suffer in life is she not gonna be able to do whatever she wants to do because she has access to money and power of course not that's not what I'm saying what I'm saying is that child has an elevated sense of what she's able to do on a Broadway stage and it's different than acting in film it's different in acting on TV if you're an echo baby it's different than being an adult stunt casting this kid has had every bad decision thrusted upon them to get to this point but above all I feel embarrassed for that casting director for that show because as somebody who should prioritize a good performance and the experience of the rest of their cast and those children involved they should be ashamed of themselves

how medieval stasis can make sense in fantasy  #skyrim #asoiaf #lotr #baldursgate3 #dnd #dungeonsanddragons#sword#fantasy#dndtiktok#dnd5e#swordtiktok#rpg
voice_to_text: Medieval stasis is a rather strange trope in the fantasy genre. If you think about it, it doesn't make too much sense that a civilization would have a late medieval to Renaissance level of technology for thousands of years. You have all of these universities, and none of them have produced any meaningful technological innovations, mundane or magical, in thousands of years. Also, in that time, fashion trends have not changed. However, I think there is a way to make medieval stasis make sense in your story. A common artistic convention in medieval art and literature is anachronism. Arthurian legend is said at the end of the Western Roman Empire, yet late medieval art of Merlin or Arthur has people dressing like this, you know, like people from the late Middle Ages. In Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, the Knight's Tale is about knights and chivalry, despite being set in Bronze Age Greece. And in Shakespeare's play Julius Caesar, the characters are described wearing doublets, which is not a garment that existed in classical Rome. And a literary conceit common in the modern fantasy genre is the found text. Stories like the Lord of the rings and the song of ice and fire are supposed to be texts from that universe translated into modern English. If you combine these two concepts, then medieval stasis makes perfect sense. The reason you can go back in time thousands of years and technology has not changed is because of unreliable narration in universe. Author does Not know what culture and technology were like thousands of years ago. So she's just describing details based on how they are in her time period, whereas in your story's real timeline, things looked a little different.

video_description: #blackgirlstravel #blackpeopletravel #blackpeopletiktok #travellife #travelnoire #blackwomantok #savannahga #savannah #blackgirlstravel #thesouth #antiracist
voice_to_text: whenever someone describes a place as having southern charm I always think they mean well they used to own slaves but they can't anymore but look at all the nice things the enslaved people built and that's lowkey the vibe of Savannah, Georgia I'm reviewing different tourist destinations based on things to do and what it's like for black people and people of color now don't get me wrong Savannah, Georgia is a really nice place to visit but being here can make you grapple with the beauty that exists in the horrible history of the United States for instance one of the best restaurants in the city called the Olde Pink House is located inside of a home that's allegedly haunted by the spirit of enslaved children now the food was spectacular but there is still something strange about eating and drinking and enjoying yourself in a place with that kind of history when you're visiting Savannah Georgia that feeling can be kind of hard to avoid because they do still have Civil War monuments and you could very much find yourself dining in restaurants that have been in service since before the Civil Rights Act and we know what that means when my friend and I went to this popular restaurant it definitely occurred to me that we might not have been allowed to eat here back in the day but what's it like right now travelling as a Black person or person of color in true southern style people are generally much kinder than other places I visited but yes as a girl raised in the south I do understand that Southerners can smile on your face and still be talking about you behind your back now I will say the city is beautiful and there's a lot to see and do and eat especially on River Street speaking of food it's also a really great foodie city this is my first time trying a South African inspired dish overall I really enjoyed my time in Savannah and unfortunately we can't erase history so I give Savannah Georgia a 7 out of ten

Does the Epistle of Jude say Jesus is god? Hey everybody, I'm Dan Mcclellan. I'm a scholar of the Bible and religion. Fit for this video is Daredevil. And in verse 5 of the one chapter in the Epistle of Jude, the author refers to either the Lord or Jesus saving Israel out of Egypt. And there are some textual questions here about which reading is most likely original. A lot of scholars think Lord is original, but as a reference to, I don't know, the god of Israel. Some people think Lord is original, but it was a reference to Jesus, because Jesus is referred to as our Lord elsewhere in the Epistle of Jude. Some people think that Jesus was original, but that it was changed. I personally think Lord was probably original, but it is probably a reference to Jesus. However, it is not identifying Jesus as god, at least not in the Trinitarian sense. I think this author is probably referring back to the traditional identification of Jesus as the angel of the Lord, who is the one who is doing an awful lot of the saving in the story of the exodus. For instance, in Exodus 3, when Moses first encounters god, it's actually, according to verse 2 anyway, the angel of the Lord, who then says, I am the god of Israel. And in Exodus 23 we have an explanation of how the angel of the Lord can be doing all this and be Claiming to be God. God says, I'm sending an angel to guard you on the way. Don't disobey him. Don't tick him off. He will not forgive your sins, because my name is in him. So the idea there would be that the divine name represents a communicable vehicle. For divine agency, authority and presence. And so, by possessing the divine name, by having it in dwelling, the angel they can identify as god. They can do what god does. And so that angel of the Lord was identified pretty quickly in Christianity with Jesus. And so I think Judas probably saying here, Jesus, as the angel of the Lord. Was the one who was involved in bringing up the people of Israel out of Egypt.

voice_to_text: if you're a fan of audio book narrator Steven Pacey I need your help  as you may know Steven Pacey narrates my book Artificial Wisdom but is also much much much better known  for narrating Joe Abercrombie's The Blade Itself and that whole First Law series all of Joe's books Steven Pacey is the nicest guy out there he is just a pleasure to work with he's a real gentleman and here's the thing when you're a narrator you're a bit disconnected from your praise Steven has tons of fans out there if you look on Reddit's first law community for example  he's often regarded as one of the best narrators of all time but he doesn't get to hear any of that  cause he doesn't go on Reddit he doesn't go on TikTok he's got no idea how much people absolutely love his work so I was chatting with him over imessage this evening and I sent him a couple of the TikToks that people have been doing about Artificial Wisdom just to show him hey look this is some of the the things people are saying about the audiobook isn't that kinda cool  and what they're saying about the book in general and he said wow I don't think I have ever really seen one of these videos before so I've got this idea tell me if I’m crazy but I would love to send Steven like a supercut of short messages of people just saying, well, whatever you wanna say really about him and his work and what it means to you what do you think of him as a narrator how you …  hey if you wanna say it about artificial wisdom great but I get it  if you if you haven't read artificial wisdom yet and you know you you know the blade itself that's absolutely fine  I don't know how else to do this but if you want to stitch what's coming up in a second I'll download it I'll supercut it I'll send it to him  and then I will tell you all what his reaction is If that sounds good to you let's go… stitch is if you had a chance to tell our favourite audiobook narrator Steven Pacey anything about what his work means to you… what would it be?

voice_to_text: I have a question for everyone. In your opinion, what is marvel's version of the Trinity? For those you that don't know, the Trinity is a concept created by DC Comics which represents three most important characters Superman, Batman, and Wonder Woman. Not only are these the three most important characters for the publisher itself, but they're also the three most important heroes within their respected universe. They are the three characters who have consistently had a month to month comic representing them since their inception. And they represent different aspects of the DC Universe. For example, Alien Man, god, hope, justice, truth. Science based superpowers, no superpowers, magic based superpowers. So what is marvel's version of the Trinity? For me, I have two answers. First, in regards to the publisher itself, it would be Wolverine, Spider Man, and the Hulk. Arguably three the most important and popular characters that Marvel has had, as well as the universes and aspects of Marvel that they represent. Wolverine himself, as well as the X Men, Spider Man in the entirety of the Spider Verse, and The Incredible Hulk and everything that stems out of him. And these are arguably the three most successful and popular comic books from Marvel. However, within the Marvel Universe, I would give it to Thor, Captain America, and Iron Man. Similar to Superman, Batman, and Wonder Woman, thematically they work as a Trinity. God, man, machine kind of magic based powers, super soldier, tech base. Even their Philosophies and the fact that like Batman, Superman and Wonder Woman, their colleagues, friends, teammates, they are seen as examples and something to look up to for the other heroes of the Marvel Universe. Similar to how Batman, Superman and Wonder Woman are looked up to by other heroes in the DC Universe. So for me publishing I gave it to Wolverine, Spider Man and the Hulk. In universe I give it to Thor, Captain America and Iron Man. So I want to know from all of you, who do you think is marvel's version of the Trinity? Please comment. Stitch Duet. I wanna know!

video_description: also i dont care if your tag line is “i talk about boys” it still doesn’t help what women in this sport have been trying to do
voice_to_text: What are the requirements for being an influencer and getting invited to a Grand Prix? Because this weekend was absolutely shocking. You can be a female in the sport and find the drivers attractive, but actually still care about the racing and F1 as a whole. But the fact that influencers are getting invited by teams that are doing the opposite of what females in the sport have been trying to push for the last couple of years is just insane to me. When you have an influencer go to an event and you have 90% of the content they post from the Grand Prix about how drivers are hot or they're only there for the drivers and not the racing, that blows my mind. Not a single piece of content I have seen from this one person has involved the car or racing or anything like that. I don't need a full depth analysis on the race from her or any of these people, but something more and not just about how they want someone that's hot or how they're only there for the hot drivers would be great. And don't get me wrong, I understand influencers are beneficial and they help reach a new target audience for Grand Prix and everything. But when your content doesn't focus on the racing or what Formula 1 actually is and only revolves around the hot F1 drivers, and you're invited by a team, that's doesn't make much sense. Also if you Get invited by a team. Please know how to spell the driver's names.

Do you prefer hard cover or paperback books? Or no preference? #booktok #bookishquestions #reader #readersoftiktok #readercommunity
voice_to_text: Hardcover or paperback books, which do you prefer? Personally, I don't have a strong preference one way or another. I feel that they both have their pros and cons. For hardback books, I like that they're sturdier. I like that I'm not worried about bending the cover as much or breaking the spine as easily. I dislike how much space they take up and I hate dealing with their dust jackets. The dust jackets drive me nuts. They bend super easily, they're in the way. And paperback books- I enjoy that they're more compact, they don't have dust jackets, but it's a lot easier to bend or break their spines just on accident and for the covers to get bent and scuffed up. I like to try to keep my books in fairly good condition as much as possible. It isn't always possible, but it's a lot harder for paperbacks. So, what about you? Hardback or paperback?

voice_to_text: The largest yacht at this year's Monaco Grand Prix is a 200 million dollar super yacht name faith. It probably cost over a million dollars to bring the boat there for the weekend, but you guys are gonna be shocked who actually owns it. So this is faith. It's a 316 foot boat that rents out for $1.5 million each week. The bedrooms have panoramic views. The interior is amazing with a gym, a pool, and a sauna. But my favorite part is probably the front of the boat, which has a heli pad in a garage for your helicopter when you aren't using it. And then when you store that helicopter away, it actually turns into a basketball court too. But the business behind a yacht like this is even more fascinating. Faith is that boat right there with the dot on it. That's a prime spot in Port Hercules and Monaco, and it probably cost the owner of $100,000 to park there this week. And when you use the general rule of thumb that an owner should expect to spend around 10% of the boat's value annually on operating cost, that includes fuel, crew, salaries, maintenance, insurance, stockage fees, and everything else. He probably spent over $1 million to bring the boat to Monaco this week. So whoever.

voice_to_text: my semi controversial take is that literary fiction is a genre I will try and make this as simple as possible but actually this is complicated as fuck so the generally accepted definition  of literary fiction is the absence of genre or book that doesn't fit into any other genre but has literary merit and I think that literary merit is exactly why it's a genre so let's unpack that  I consider the concept of genre through practical lens rather than an analytical one and that is as a classification for readers or booksellers or publishers or anyone to categorise a book practically speaking if it could theoretically have its own section in a bookshop I would consider it to be a genre and there I just wanna point out that general fiction is a genre and it is different from literary what sets them apart is that literary fiction has literary merit and obviously literary merit is very subjective but I argue that literary fiction is written with the intention of having literary merit while general fiction's intended purpose is predominantly to entertain but what is considered literary merit a lot of the time this will be deep insights into the human condition or how we understand society or pushing the boundaries of what we can achieve with language and I would argue that these are tropes and yes these books are intended to challenge but the way in which they challenge is often trophy there are very few things that have never been done before when I pick up a book of one of these days I'm not surprised if there's no punctuation what does make this a bit more complicated is that literary can often be blended with other genres in a way that most other genres don't do quite so much say Jonathan Strange & Mister norrell for example I call it fantasy it's got magicians it's got but it was longlisted for the Man Booker prise back when it was still called that it is officially classified with literary fiction but at the same time you can have romance fantasy you can have historical crime all genres can be combined with other genres except for general fiction which I think is the true absence of genre if you put general fiction into a historical setting it becomes historical if you put a major romance plot into a general fiction it is a romance the second somebody considers something in a general fiction about literary merit the genre shifts now I'm sure that there are many academics who would disagree with this but I think practically from a consumer standpoint it's a genre  so next time somebody is snobby about genre fiction show them this  see what they say

voice_to_text: this is what it's really like being a rockstar's girlfriend for context I am married to Feisal from the band loathe some things are as cool as they seem for instance being backstage at Download Festival and being invited into deftones area like meeting deftones meeting Chino in the flash get a fight with him like I was still there thinking like oh my god why am I here and also I've been a fan of you guys since I was like 13 having Paramore be fans of your man's band that is unreal being in the backstage family room with Hayley Williams having Taylor called me Ellie which is like my nickname like my name is Eleanor and people call me Ellie and he's like Ellie I'm like what nicest nicest band in the world so so lovely meeting Charlie from busted and having him give me a kiss on the cheek after him saying that he's loved my husband's band for like 2 years my childhood cured however some things are not as cool as they seem you have to be okay with uncertainty in the calendar plans change last minute dates get cancelled booking a holiday a year in advance is just a silly move things are up in the air a lot that you have to be okay with that I'm an actor luckily so I totally understand so our schedules kind of are perfect for each other cause we just know that nothing's ever set in stone like we could go on holiday and I might have to fly back for an important audition or he might book us a few nights away from a night and then he's like called into the studio last minute like that kind of thing or you plan to have a date night but he's late because of rehearsals or writing it's such like you can't get angry at that that's just part past of the relationship you'll either be together 24 7 or not at all like tours can last months and it's not easy missing someone I'm 5 months pregnant and my husband is away for 7 weeks and like I'm struggling at the minute I really miss him backstage is just not always this glam rock and roll thing that's portrayed in movies and on Pinterest boards and things like that it's often a cramped room with not enough chairs a lot of waiting around and sometimes it can be really really really boring there's so much more that I can say on that so let me know if you'd like part 2

voice_to_text: why does New York City it seems super unfriendly but at the same time super helpful hi my name is Amalia I speak a whole bunch of languages I'm a professional Tibetan English interpreter and when I travel I like analyzing the different cultures of the places I'm in even my own home but let's take this conversation somewhere a little more quiet New York City has an extremely high population density in fact it is the most densely populated city in the United States it's also a bastion of East Coast culture unsurprisingly and the East Coast is really strong and it's belief that you should have privacy and personal space how do you do that when you're surrounded by people New Yorkers generally respect your personal bubble but that bubble has to be really really tiny what does this mean when hundreds of you are jammed onto a subway car no eye contact no smiles nothing that would break the bubble and yeah smiling at you is a form of communication so it breaks the bubble, by not smiling by not making eye contact by not nodding at you they are saying “you are in your own space and I am respecting that space” but as I'm sure you've seen the moment you need assistance they're going to jump in anyone who lives in New York City has seen someone look confused and go “does anyone know where such-and-such stop is?” at which point everyone breaks their bubbles and they come over and they say “okay this line” “oh wait” “you're going to the stop right after?” “can you can you show them?” and then the moment the problem is solved back to bubble so it's not actually unfriendliness it's respect of your space in a very densely populated city

voice_to_text: tell me about your writing journey mine I don't know where I started I've always been a lover of stories the fairy tales or family history whatever it is and I was always conjuring tales and making up my own I was the youngest of three and my brothers are a decade and a half older than I am so I've kind of been the only child in my house throughout my childhood and I was surrounded by adults or young adults so I was raised rather quickly I think I was I guess always seen as older than I was or treated as older than older than I was so I always made up stories conjured friends just all those things and other friends and I would take stories and shows that we loved and films and then going play live action fanfiction out in the garden from there it evolved and after I lost my grandad at the age of 11 I started to write stream of consciousness poetry just to get stuff out of me I didn't know how to fix it so I kind of wrote and that's how I survived that through the grief um and then I started going from there to full on novels from sort of 14 onwards moving on from that continuing through my teenage years I was writing constantly and then at the age of 28 I had inherited published it's no longer available it was a wonderful wonderful experience and I Learned so much about the process through that and as a writer but I didn't stop I continue to write and now obviously I have many books to finish under my belt um I've got a lot to edit and get out into the world but the legends of Evernyl trilogy  book 1 is coming out early next year and we've got the other two books and others that I'm continually working on so I'm constantly writing so that's my kind of journey and I'm learning all the time with each pit stop along the way I mean this one has been such an amazing experience because I've Learned more and more and more as you go along I think each book does teach you something so yeah that's what's happened so I'd love to hear more about your journeys and how you got to where you've gotten to and where you'd like to go

in the never ending discourse of reviews are for readers not for authors one of the craziest things that I keep coming across is something that has not happened to me luckily but I do see where somebody will get an arc will read an arc which is an advanced reader copy a review copy of a book before its publication sent out for review um and an author that is saying if you have a review that is 3 stars or below essentially if you have anything negative to say about the book at all withhold your review do not post your review until at least two weeks after the release of the book what the fuck and like not only is it crazy to me that there are some authors who are making this demand but that there are a not insignificant amount of people who think that this is okay think that this is how the industry does and should work and will defend that on people's videos where they say you know they're reviewing an arc negatively and being like well didn't they say not to post this review for two weeks shouldn't you be not posting this review is this is really unprofessional of you to post this post this before the book comes out what the fuck because what that sounds like to me is that an author is saying you know don't post any negative reviews for you know at least the first two weeks of the book being out despite the fact that I sent you a copy for review what that is saying to me is that the author is interested in tricking consumers right like the idea is that you don't want any potential consumers going to the Goodreads page or TikTok or wherever and finding any kind of negative review within the first two weeks you want consumers to think that there are only positive reviews that your book is so good that nobody dislikes it everybody thinks it's five stars despite the fact that that's not true you've just told people who don't think that that they're not allowed not allowed to post for the first two books of the first two weeks of books release right like you're you're tricking consumers you're lying to consumers to get them to buy your book that's fucking crazy right because to circle back to the beginning reviews are for readers not for authors right so authors don't get to curate their reviews to look however they want them to look spite reality so that they can make sales right they can trick consumers into buying their but like what the fuck for some like arbitrary amount of time until they finally decide like okay now you're allowed to post your negative reviews if you're an arc reader please post your review if you are if you have a negative review just post it I read an arc last year and put it on my most disappointing reads of the entire year four months before it came out right that sucked I was really excited for that book but like it's a review the review is supposed to be your honest opinion of the book that the author should be seeking honest opinions honest reviews honestly having only 5 star reviews is very strange whatever this is a huge red flag thing if an author is asking you not to post negative reviews for X Men that's a huge red flag what the fuck

My kids aren't big snackers, but today they requested some cheeses after seeing them at the store the other day, so I decided to just make them some. These are super simple and quick to make, so I started off by shredding some cheddar cheese, combining that in my stand mixer with some salt and butter. Then mix mix it all until it's pretty much combined before adding in some flour and some really cold water. Once that all comes together, I into a disc and spread it on some plastic wrap before popping it in the fridge for about an hour and a half. After it's chilled I pull it back out. Usually I cut it in half so it's easier to handle for using my rolling pin to get it as thin as I can, and then slice in whatever shape I want. Usually it's tiny rectangles or squares. Place those on a Parchment line baking tray before using the end of a chopstick to put a small hole in the middle so they resemble Cheez its. After I've done that with all of them, I pop them in the oven for about 10 minutes, let them cool, and then place them in my glass jar. That's how I usually store them, but my kids had all of these in one sitting.

video_description: She raggedy #bridgerton #ladywhistledown #tvreview #greenscreen
voice_to_text: Eloise is one of those  hauex who be riding  with Susan B Anthony.  if you are not  to date with Bridgerton. Eloise is supposed to be  this strong feminist character. This season made me realize  that she is a feminist by default. I personally don't think that  she cares too much about  the patriarchal system but more about how  it affects her specifically. Because we see that she  is enjoying every aspect  of being a rich socialite the outfits,the balls, the promenades, like that is her jam, she loves being there it's not mandatory that she go. She grew up in a family  that has no worries and she was born right  in the sweet spot where she didn't have pressure  the way that  Anthony and Daphne did  I think the real reason why  she's upset with Penelope  being Whistledown is because she's jealous. Penelope is living the life  that she has been  saying she wants. This season is making  me realize that Eloise  always saw Penelope  as an accessory. I don't even think  she can fathom  the idea of Penelope  making a match. Penelope has always  been there to make  Eloise feel better because let's be real here there's nothing that Whistledown can say that could threaten  the standing of the Bridgertons they are way too rich  and impactful and  Eloise knows that. That’s why she be running  around here like a fool because she is infallible. She knows her standing  and she knows that everyone  wants to be her and you know what she likes it. I can't believe how much I like Cressida this season  because unlike Penelope Cressida is Eloises equal. Eloise is fighting for her  life to regain that dominance that she had in her former friendship and Cressida ain't having it. I'm glad because she needs  someone who she views as an equal let her know about herself. Because she's so concerned  with maintaining her own status quo she can't even realize  when other people are trying to make sure that they keep it Cressida is trying to secure  a bag for the two of them has she she trying to block her blessing it's weird. Finally I feel like Eloise  is so gung ho on making sure  that she doesn't marry that, I don't know agricultural vegan guy, because she feels like Penelope  will never have any options and I think that she's gonna  be so upset with  Penelope and Colin getting engaged not because she's  Lady Whistledown but because she doesn't  think that Penelope deserves Colin in her head Penelope  is not of the same stature  or the same make as people like Cressida and herself. Because we all know if Eloise  was Lady Whistledown, which I know she wish she was she wouldn't tell a soul, and if Penelope was out here  talking about I will tell your betrothed  if you don't you would drag that  woman through the MUD. She is swifty in that way she's gonna use feminism  against her I got this girl's number.

voice_to_text: If you saw my last video, you know that I found the cutest bookstore and flower shop today, okay? And in that, I got the greatest, most exciting find, probably of not my life, but it's pretty high up there. First and foremost, I got a really cute shirt, so I'm gonna try fancy transition. Okay, ready? Is this shirt not the cutest thing ever? Okay. Book club baddie. I have not one, but two book clubs that I started. Okay? I have one here on TikTok that you can go to my linktree, and if you scroll down, it's through fable. But that's one of my book clubs that there's, like, 300 of us hanging out there, so always a plug. Go join that one. But then I also have a very small one with my just, like, really close friends, so I feel like this was a very fitting shirt to have. And just because it's a bookish shirt, I needed it. But that's not the greatest thing that I found. I found an indie copy of Things We Never Got Over, like Miss Lucy score. If you open this up and you see the publishing right there, it's. That's what she said. Publishing. This is not Bloom. This is an indie copy. And I just happened to stumble upon this today. Am I over the moon? Yes. Did I love this book? Yes. Was it one of those books that just, like, got me and hooked me? Into small town romance? Yes. Is it my favorite of the series? Also, yes. So the fact now that I have the traditionally published and the indie version of this makes my whole life. And if anyone wants to know the difference really fast, I will show you. So this one is, like, glossy. This one is matte. This is the traditionally published. This is the indie published. The spines are different. This one is obviously through Bloom. And then the backs are also different. And again, this is the indie, and this is the traditionally published, and they're about the same length. But for research purposes, I feel like this is just a perfect time for me to go back and reread things we never got over. voice_to_text: Read a novel. How similar is the first draft to the last draft? What a good question. How similar is the first draft to the last draft? They tend to be very similar, except for all the important things. Writing a novel, for me, tends to be almost like the process of throwing Mudder to wall and seeing what shapes it make, and then going, you know, that really looks like a face over there, and throwing some more MUD. And then the second draft is the process of going in and making it look like you knew what you were doing the whole time. I tend. When I originally started writing novels, I would. I would write my novels on the computer, and I never really felt I had any difference between drafts. I just had a first draft that got better and often got bigger. So part of the fun for me now is I go out when I start a new novel, and I buy some fountain pens and I buy some big old notebooks. I write novels by hand. And this means two important things. 1. Nobody can send me email while I'm writing or pop up messages, and I cannot suddenly decide to look up a word while I'm writing. And. And find myself four hours later in the middle of some eBay auction. The Google search LED me to. If I'm sitting there, you know, I, I, it's me in a notebook. I'm just Gonna have to go and look it up in a dictionary. And there's the fact that once I finished it, I then get to sit down and start typing. And I know the shape of the thing, and I know how it ended. And I can decide what to throw out. And I can look at it. And then that draft is what goes to my editor. In the case of A Nancy boys, I wrote maybe an additional four scenes after it came back from my editor. Most mostly because there were characters she really liked. That she didn't feel got enough for one of a better word screen time. So, um, I wrote some more scenes about them. Maeve Livingston got three extra scenes cause my editor liked her.
