video_description: Miss USA steps down and leaves a cryptic resignation letter, with the first letter of every sentence spelling out “I AM SILENCED.”  #missusa #missteenusa
voice_to_text: Miss USA steps down and leaves a cryptic resignation letter with the first letter of every sentence spelling out I am silence. Here's what's happening. Noella Void, who was crowned Miss USA in 2023 on Monday, announced that she would be resigning her title in order to protect her mental health. She posted this announcement on social media, but eaglelied internet sluice noticed something strange. It appears to be an acrostic with the first letter of every sentence spelling out the secret message I am silence. That is, until the final three sentences, which begin with the letters H, I, and P. Fans are still speculating on what those final letters could mean, with some suggestand initials. Only two days after Void's resignation, Uma Sophia Servastia, who was named Miss Teen USA in November 2023, handed in her crown as well. In a statement, Servastia, 17, said she was resigning because, quote, my personal values no longer fully align with the direction of the organization. She did not elaborate further. The dual resignations triggered a wave of still growing intrigue on social media. Some guess Voit may have created the secret message because she is under a non disclosure agreement and is not permitted to speak publicly. Others say this is all just a coincidence. Do you think the beauty pageants were trying to send a message? Let us know in the comments.

I know this may lose me author mutuals, but definitions matter. Yes ARCs are a way of marketing and at your discretion, but reviewers' honesty and integrity matter as well. If all you want is positivity, what you want is a hype team not an arc team. Also, as a reminder to reviewers, never tag an author in a negative review. #booktok #authortok #bookreview #arcreader
voice_to_text: so authors we kind of need to have a little chat here um this is gonna be geared more towards indie authors um but I think with the recent discourse going on around arcs because it's always around arcs um I think what a lot of you guys want is not an actual arc team what you want is a hype team and those are two vastly different things a hype team is there to push your books out say how great they are that kind of stuff um leading up to a release and immediately following a release an arc team an actual honest arc team is people who received an advance reader copy of your book in exchange for an honest review but a lot of times when you go and you sign up for an arc you see all these weird stipulations like if it's a review below 4 stars please withhold for three weeks until after the book's release that is that's dishonesty because it's like a lie by omission um and I don't feel that any stipulations should be put on reviews like as a reviewer and so like if I see that kind of stuff I typically I won't sign up for the arc um because it feels like a way of dishonesty and I don't wanna be dishonest to those that follow me and I don't wanna like if I have a lot of feelings on a book I'm going to want to say them so um yes I think definitions matter if you want an arc team you want honest then you want honest reviews posted whenever they wanna post them if you want a hype team you just want people to speak good about your book leading up to and after the release so really think about what you want and call it the proper thing because there are people that are scared like reviewers that are afraid to sign up for arcs or to be blacklisted from getting arcs because they left want to leave a negative review and they shouldn't because that doesn't disservice to themselves because it's like you're lying to yourself and you're lying to your followers and it does readers who are looking at reviews for a book their own thing because what their yuck may have been might be someone else's yum so you never know I honestly think though that like I said guys do you want an arc team or do you want a hype team you can have both but you shouldn't punish your arc readers in or pressure them into withholding a review

voice_to_text: so how does this whole pay off each other's debt by watching videos thing work let me break it down piece by piece I've gotten a lot of questions about this so basically you have to reach a certain threshold to be a part of TikTok's Creator Rewards program which I'll start referring to a CRP moving forward so to qualify for the CRP you have to have 10,000 followers and have gotten at least 100,000 views in the 30 days prior to when you reach 10,000 followers once you hit that threshold TikTok will invite you to join the Creator Rewards program and at that point moving forward any videos you post will be you know eligible for rewards now a lot of people have asked like I'm so far from 10,000 I don't think I'll ever make it there or I don't like posting videos or being perceived on this app now keep in mind every job or role or passion or hobby has its own fit for you like you will find the things that you shine in if this isn't one of those then your role in this whole movement is to watch and to repost which I do both right so I'm a part of the CRP but I also watch like and repost videos to help others reach more rewards the reason why TikTok is likely not upset at this movement is because it's feeding into what their goals are too it's a win win for us and for TikTok it still keeps us on the app it keeps us focusing on FYP it keeps us engaging with content that's really what they want and that's why they set up the Creator Rewards program too is because they know that we as creators are the entertainment on this app that we are the education we are what you stay for and ultimately you as the creator if you are part of the CRP are the one paying off your debt with the help of a community that's engaging with your content so much so that you get to reach a certain level of rewards to enable that financial freedom to exist and again this isn't going to be for everyone cause not everyone's caught out for being a content machine that's like a very specific skill set and that's okay if you're not I can create another video if you want about other scalable forms of income that rely a little bit less on your labor so if you want me to post something about revenue source or income ideas let me know and I'll post that video

voice_to_text: a question for my fellow authors what is the mechanic or thing that shows up in all of your books as always I'll go first so I've come to realise that I put a Florence Nightdale scene in almost every single one of my book if you don't know what a Florence Night Gale scene is it is when one of the main characters is injured or ill and the other main character takes care of them and for me in these scenes this is usually when I have uh one or both of the characters realise that they have feelings for the other or that their feelings are actually love it's usually a turning point in my books um where something emotional is revealed now do I put these scenes in because I am a chronically ill disabled author and I love the idea of having people take care of me even though I never let people take care of me cause I don't wanna be a burden maybe but we're not here to talk about that I'm an author I give my characters my trauma so I don't have to deal with it myself

voice_to_text: Booktok Hot takes there's a possibility that this will flop, but that's okay because I'm just happy to be here. Starting off on a possibly controversial note. Just because a book is considered a classic doesn't mean it's a good book. Today and let me explain. Moving on. No. 2 book talk is not the issue when it comes to drama. People are a community of people who like to read. Books as a whole are not at fault for the sexualization of others. The individuals who are leaving comments and making video sexualizing others are. Most of us on Book Talk are just minding our business and reading about immortal fairies, dragons, and mama tails so that we can try to forget the fact that we can't afford to buy a house and will probably never be able to retire. No.3 this isn't even a hot take because I think we all collectively agree that stickers on books, especially the fake ones, should be illegal. If anyone knows who the person was who suggested to publishers that they perform such a hate crime, please let me know because I like to pay them a visit. No. 4 romance books are just as valid as high fantasy, SCI fi, etcetera. This one is really just directed at the toxic fantasy bros who think if you don't spend your time reading 20+ book series, you weren't actually a reader. To them, I say, uh, shut the fuck up. As we All know I'm not a romance, but that doesn't mean I won't fight for their rights. Going off of that, romance books are also for men. Debut books should not get special treatment when it comes to reviews. And this one I do actually want to explain. Regardless if it's the first book an author has put out or the 30th, if there are areas that a reader believes needed improvement, they are allowed to express that, because at the end of the day, they spent their money on it. And when you purchase something, there's an expectation when it comes to quality that's attached to that. Also, I'm sure that there are other people like myself, who are usually unaware when it comes to what is and isn't a debut. For example, one dark window. I had no fucking clue that that was a debut. Was I impressed when I was informed that it was? Yeah, but did it change my review of the book? No. Someone who is currently writing a book, the last thing I want is for people to go easy on me because it's a debut. If I write something and there are areas that need to be worked on, I want to know so that I can improve for the next one. And lastly, and probably most importantly, because we really need to discuss this, uh, Cassian's anatomy is alarmingly large and would kill somebody. If I were Nesta, I would be fascinated for A good 13 seconds, and then I'd scream and run for the fucking hills. Listen, I love a challenge, but that one, that. That's not it. There are limits, these sort of things. And he passed it so long ago. I mean, he's going 80 in a 25 mile per hour zone. And while speeding can be fun, sometimes at a certain point you're just being insane and begging to crash. Or at least asking for a speeding ticket, which nobody wants.

He growled softly and deathly, flipped us over, spreading me beneath him as he wrenched his lips from my mouth and made a trail of kisses down my neck. My entire world constricted to the touch of his lips on my skin. Everything beyond them, beyond him, was a void of darkness and moonlight. My back arched as he reached the spot he once bitten, and I dragged my hands through his hair, savoring the silk and smoothness. He traced the arc of my hip bones, lingering at the edge of my undergarments. My nightgown had become hitched around my waist, but I didn't care. I hooked my bare legs around his, running my feet down the hard muscles of his calves. He breathed my name onto my chest.

voice_to_text: hey bookish friends Rachal the writer here with another author chat today we're talking about the recap chapter this is that chapter that a lot of authors include kind of at the beginning of their book uh that is it's in a series right so in the second or third book where they just kind of do this recap through the character's perspective of what happened in the previous book um but they do it in a way where it's like the character's remembering what happened and reference it a lot and I wanna know your thoughts about that cause I'm personally not a huge fan of the full recap chapter and and I'm of two minds of this the first is that I typically if I have the series of books then I have just read I've just read the book prior to that and I don't need the recap um and in the case of books where you're waiting for the release of the next book when that next book comes out I typically reread the book before it or the books before it before I read that one so it's fresh in my mind I don't find a recap chapter helpful in that case because I'm not gonna remember because I read so much stuff in fact I recently read a reread a series and I remembered so much from like the first three books but by the time I got to the end of the series that I have read three times I didn't remember anything from that last book don't know why cause I've read all of those books at least three times but for my brain a recap chapter just really doesn't do it for me um it's kind of the same thing where like if I'm given the option on a streaming service to skip the recap of previously on whatever show I was watching I will skip it because I was just watching it my dude I know what happened um so for me like it doesn't make sense to have a full like beginning of the book kind of dedicated to recapping what happened in the previous book I do think it is helpful to provide some sort of like transition between the two books so some time has passed um and allowing the characters to reflect on it bits and pieces but reflecting on the entirety of the whole previous book feels unnecessary but if you can do it in a way where it's just like you know the character kind of like oh after I finished this I did this you know um or it had been like three weeks since we got back from all that ridiculousness like that works because it's like ah you know and that also will help somebody who's picking up the book not realizing it's the next book in the series I mean like oh there's something that happened before this I need to go find that book um so that's my thought on recap chapters I don't like them I I sprinkle the recap of my story like for the second book that's coming up in the Bound Prophecy series I promise it's coming haha got a little sidetracked with this book and uh another book I'm writing but anyway uh I am kind of sprinkling bits and pieces to kind of transition into the next storyline but I'm not dedicating the whole beginning chapter to like so we did this and we did that and we did that and now we're here um and that's just my take on it I'm not like bashing anybody who chooses to do that I'm just saying for me personally I'm not a fan of the recap chapter but let's chat about it in the comments below tell me what you think let's have a nice little conversation discourse about it and yeah happy writing and we'll see you later

voice_to_text: how did so many people  fall in love with such a bad idea? James Scott points us to Italian general Giulio Douhet and his 1921 book The Command of the Air Douhet thought that modern warfare would  bypass armies and battlefields altogether as bomber pilots reached the  vital centers of an opposing nation bringing such “horror and suffering” the people themselves will rise up  and overthrow their government to end the war Robert Pape, in his 1996 book, Bombing to Win, looks at several historic examples and tells us that “low to moderate levels” of bombing “inspire more anger than fear” “heavy bombardment produces apathy,” “not rebellion” similarly, Jean Mayer, in her 1975 article on famine relief tells us that “Contrary to popular belief,” famines are “rarely accompanied by revolution” gravely underfed people are “too feeble”  and too preoccupied with just surviving “to initiate and follow through” on a revolution so if you want people to overthrow a government that they themselves do not like or trust two things will prevent that—  bombing and famine I hope nobody's wishing the tumult of revolution on top of all the trauma  that some populations have already recently suffered but if you do wanna see  a change of course  people need a break

Here’s what the three-time Super Bowl champion said about women, Pride Month, COVID, abortion, and more … If you want to read or sign the petition, head to our link in bio. #HarrisonButker #commencement #graduation #chiefs #nfl
voice_to_text: I think it is you, the women, who have had the most diabolical lies told to you. How many of you are sitting here now, about to cross this stage and are thinking about all the promotions and titles you are going to get in your career? Some of you may go on to lead successful careers in the world, but I would venture to guess that the majority of you are most excited about your marriage and the children you will bring into this world. I can tell you that my beautiful wife, Isabel, would be the first to say that her life truly started when she began living her vocation as a wife and as a mother. By making it to this moment through all the adversity thrown your way from COVID, I hope you learn the important lessons that suffering in this life is only temporary. As a group, you witnessed firsthand how bad leaders who don't stay in their lane can have a negative impact on society. While COVID might have played a large role throughout your formative years, it is not unique. Bad policies and poor leadership have negatively impacted major life issues. Things like abortion, IVF, surrogacy, euthanasia, as well as a growing support for degenerate cultural values in media, all stem from the pervasiveness of this order. Our own nation is LED by a man who publicly and proudly proclaims his Catholic faith, but at the same time is delusional enough to make The sign of the cross during a pro abortion rally. He has been so vocal in his support for the murder of innocent babies that I'm sure to many people, it appears that you can be both Catholic and pro choice. The world around us says that we should keep our beliefs to ourselves. Whenever they go against the tyranny of diversity, equity and inclusion, we fear speaking truth. Because now, unfortunately, truth is in the minority. Congress just passed a Bill we're stating. Something as basic as the biblical teaching of who killed Jesus? Could land you in jail. I'm certain the reporters at the AP did not have imagined that their attempt to rebuke and embarrass places and people like those here have been addicting. Wouldn't be met with anger, but instead met with excitement and pride. Not the deadly sins sort of pride that has an entire month dedicated to it, but the true god centered pride that is cooperating with the Holy Ghost to glorify him.

voice_to_text: We're used to the Lord of the rings sounding like this, but that's not what it originally sounded like. Early in 1965, the British composer Donald Swan decided to set some of the poems from the Lord of the rings to music, wrote to Tolkien's publishers about his idea, and he soon met the professor at his daughter Priscilla Tolkien's house, since she was the only one who had a piano there. They sat around the piano and Swan played some of the music for Tolkien. First song he played was called The Road Goes Ever On, which in the books was written by Bilbo in his first song by him. At the end of The Hobbit, when Bilbo returns to the shire and sees his home again for the first time, he sings it again in the Lord of the rings, and Frodo sings some verses from it too. And in the film we hear Gandalf sing some of the verses. So Swans music and talking verses were collected into this book. The Road Goes ever wrong, probably the most beautifully produced Tolkien book from his own lifetime, with Tolkien providing the necessary Tangwa scripts and Swan the music.

I love being his wife. I am just not an NFL wife. That shouldn't be what my entire life succumbs to. I choose to follow my husband to whatever state football brings him to. voice_to_text: Being a Marine Corps veteran that works in the firearm industry, I run into a lot of this. I swear to god at least once a day someone tells me there were some sort of Special Forces or a Marine or something along the lines. Being a Marine Corps veteran, super easy to spot what makes the grass grow? They don't know the answer to that fucking question, they're a fucking liar. And if someone claims that they were a Navy SEAL, I have watched enough Don Shipley to know what questions to ask them. People saying that they were a Navy SEAL or a Marine are the two most common Stolen Valor claims I hear. I had an older fat white dude come in one day and claim that he was the Navy SEAL that killed Ben Laden. Now a simple Google search will tell you that's not fucking true. He also told me that he didn't know what a drager was, so he wasn't a Navy SEAL ever to begin with. Another prime example is I had a gentleman come in and tell me that he was the lead general for the Marine Corps back in the early eighties. He didn't say comment on, he said lead general. And once again, a simple Google search told me that that was not true. What's the craziest stolen valor story that you've heard? Leave it in the comments and don't forget to follow!

voice_to_text: I am an absolutely feral book reader, which means I read 37 books in April and I'm gonna rapid fire tell you which ones I think are worth reading or not. Did I love it? Would I recommend it? Yes or no? Let's go first up. I read the whole Shatter me series. I love this, dystopian young adult. I know the reading style is quite poetic so it's not for everyone, but these are just so good. I love them. The Caraval series. I read this so I could read once upon a Broken Heart first because this is the prequel series. I'd say it was like a 3.75 series. I did really enjoy it. It just wasn't like my favourite read ever. But very magical and very enchanting. Very fun to read. Then of course, once upon a Broken Heart. Four and a 1/2 Star series. This is so good. Worth it. I would recommend reading Caraval first. It just made it so much more enjoyable. I did read the third one, but on Kindle cause paperback version is not out yet. Speaking of Kindle, I read the entire Zodiac Academy and some of the novellas. I just love this series so much. 5 star series! Individual books, ratings vary. But like overall 5 stars. 5 fucking stars. If you want a big fantasy adult series that has some spice in it, read the Zodiac Academy. I know it's a bully romance, It's intense. It's not for everyone. If you want a happily ever after fantasy, You know, princess whimsical happy vibes. Yeah, don't read the Zodiac Academy. If you like intense, morally grey men. Maybe even just - they're so far past morally grey to be honest, but a whole magical world where Fae are ruthless. Read The Zodiac Academy, another one of my favourite series ever. Lightlark and nightbane, both 5 stars. Please read these. The last 80 pages of both of these books are absolutely unhinged in the best way possible. One of my favorites. 5 stars. The Shepherd King duology. My first Gothic Fantasy reads. This one was four and a 1/2 stars. This one was 5 stars. 5 stars together. So fun. Such a unique magic system. If you like fantasy books, read these. This is great. What lies beyond the veil and what hunts inside the shadows Two stars. I (personally) would not read again. Did not finish the series. The Red Queen. I feel like it's an iconic fantasy book. Like everyone has read this. A 3.75. I really enjoyed the book. I read it in one sitting. It's just not my favourite ever. The story has sort of been done so many different ways in fantasy books. The concept isn't anything that I've not read before, but I still very much enjoyed it. I read The Crowns of Nyaxia on Kindle because it's on Kindle Unlimited. I would say 3.5 stars. I like the first one, didn't really enjoy the second one. Kinda lost me there. I LOVE the author's Writing style, so I'm still gonna read her other books. Characters for this just didn't do it for me. I think I was expecting more from how hyped it was, but the novella In between the two. Six scorched Roses, 4.5 stars my favourite novella I have ever read. I love this so much. These characters were so much more interesting and I think it's worth reading like book one to be able to just read the novella. You can read the novella alone, but the novella, honestly. Mmm. So good. Powerful novella. I honestly did not think that I was going to enjoy this as much as I did, but Lauren Roberts has just me in a chokehold. Like her writing style, the way she writes. I'm just so drawn in. Wondering if powerless was maybe gonna be like a one off, but after reading this I was like, no, I know what it is. She just knows how to write exactly what I want. And then finally I read the first book in the bargainer series. Love the premise of this. They really had me in like the first 2/3, but like the ending I just wasn't really a fan of so it brought it down for me. Made me not want to continue reading. I probably will go back and read it. There were a few things with the books and the characters that weren't my favourites. Yeah, I don't know. It wouldn’t be on my top List of recommendations, but I wouldn't advise against reading it. I think I need to read more of the series to give a fair judgement. That's every book that I read in April. Again. Absolutely unhinged, I know.

voice_to_text: We are just gonna hop right into this one. Things and books I don't give a fuck about. Part two. It was requested and now I have some more stuff. Um, number one, epilogues that are not at least a year or more in time. Listen, epilogue can literally make or break your book in my personal opinion. I don't give a fuck about what happened three days later. No, when I get to the epilogue, I need to see damn near five years later. Seven years later. Give me some time. So we're a whole bunch of shit didn't happen. I need to see marriage, kids, divorce, somebody that went to jail, somebody is dead. I don't. Something three days later. Hell, I know what y'all doing. Y'all still in the living room where I left y'all on the last page of the book? Yeah. I don't give a fuck about your epilogue if it's not at least a year in time after that last page in the book. Romance novels with too many damn tropes. And I solely blame TikTok for this because I feel like authors now really have an insight to readers minds. And we sit and talk about our favorite tropes every fucking day on here. And they have taken that shit too hard. Cause what the fuck is a second chance? Enemies of lovers, instant love, fake dating, bully romance. I know you was confused writing this, so how the fuck you think I Feel reading it. Exactly. Stop doing that shit. And the last one. Detailed descriptions of the main characters, house. Or any characters, honestly. Um, I don't give a fuck about what their dressers look like, and 9 times out of 10, y'all gonna give us a clean cream. And bright. You just fucking described it. Insane asylum. Is she crazy? Like, is the main character crazy? Is that what you trying to tell me? Is that a context clue? I need to know these things, because once you do that. Now I'm thinking about other stuff, so I don't care about those.

voice_to_text: I wanna know what you base your one to five star reviews on like what is your criteria for a 1 2 3 4 5 star book don't generally give out one star reviews if I feel like the book is a one star I just don't review it I don't leave any kind of review on any kind of social platform a two star review I don't really give those out either but if I do, something for me that is a two star is something that I did finish the book but I absolutely had to power through and probably skim like quickly skim read the last several pages A three star review for me looks like, I did finish it obviously it wasn't great but it wasn't bad probably not something I'll recommend it just, it's kinda wishy washy just depends on how I feel at the time but wasn't a bad book a four star review for me looks like I really enjoyed the book I will probably talk about it a little bit I'll probably recommend it but I will probably never go back to it as a not rereader a five star review for me is something I would absolutely reread again I don't even keep all the books I read once I read them they usually go into a sack or box until the box gets full enough I take it to my local “We buy books” store and then I use that money to buy more books if I kept the book it's absolutely a five star read it's something I would 100% go back and reread it's something I have not stopped thinking about since I read it it's something I desperately wish that I could go back and reread again for the first time and something that I will shout from the rooftops is one of the best books I've ever read that is my rating system and I am very curious to find out other people's rating systems so let me know how you, what your criteria is for rating books one through five

voice_to_text: Alright, so I seen this Twitter post a while ago and it was basically saying why do people complain about self inserts and shows like Velma and that Starfire comic book, but not in shows like Regular Show and Smiling Friends? Which I feel like is honestly a very stupid question cause it's very easy to understand why people don't like the self inserts in Velma as opposed to Regular Show and smiling friends. First off, in Smiling Friends and Regular Show all the characters are original characters, so even if they are just the creators, it comes off as more authentic because it's a new character. And like, Regular Show is a show about two slackers, and JG Quintel has probably been a slacker once in his life and just said why not put myself in the show? It'll make it way easier to write. Whereas with Mindy Kaling she just took a character that already existed and just made it her. And I think most people would have been cool with the new interpretation of Velma. But if you're just gonna take a character and make it you, why did it even have to be Velma in the first place? Like why not just make it Mindy Killings mysteries or something at that point? Also, I don't wanna see anyone complaining about this show on my feed ever again. Cause y'all say y'all hate this show, but this show is always in the top 10 so somebody must Be watching it later.

voice_to_text: anti Zionist Jewish author Sim Kern here and I'm so excited to see how many influencers have started adopting families from Gaza to help Erin Hattamer on TikTok particularly is doing great work pairing up larger influencers with families in need but I'm also seeing creators with followings 10 times larger than mine struggling to raise a fraction of what we raised over here which is over $100,000 for three different families over the last two and a half weeks so if it's not too presumptuous I think I can help and whether you have a hundred followers or a million I think these tips are gonna help you maximize your fundraising the first mistake I'm seeing is making stand alone fundraising content it just doesn't do well people are overwhelmed by the scale of the suffering and when they see from the first second of a video that you've got a sad face on and you're using a sad voice and you're in front of a gofundme donation page they're just not they're gonna swipe on by because they're overwhelmed I'm looking at pass the hat creators pages and I'm seeing the numbers of their regular content doing 10 times the numbers of their fundraising content give your best content to the people of Gaza by sticking a little fundraising ask to the end of your normal content whatever you do best funny skits fashion beauty blogging political analysis make the your best content you can and stick the fundraising ask at the end that brings me to the second mistake which is making the fundraising ask too long it is so much more effective to keep it short and again stick it on daily make it just a part of every single content that you make rather than having one long video where you're telling like the whole saga of this family it's not needed you are an influencer your followers are going to donate to this family because it's important to you they trust you that you've chosen a good cause just highlight one or two details about the family that connect with you that made you feel a personal connection to them and put that out there but stick it to the end of every single video and keep that fundraising ask part a minute or less if possible the third mistake creators are making is you're not doing a giveaway giveaways are so effective I made a whole video on the evolutionary psychology that underpins my fundraising approach but if that's  too long; didn't watch  just in a nutshell our brains are hard wired to love a giveaway to love a little bit of gambling offer to reward your followers with the donation by giving away one item I'm giving away one signed author copy of my book a week that's it if I were to be donating my profits from this book I only make a buck or two off each book that I sell depending on the format so I would have to sell tens of thousands of copies of books to raise the amount of money I've raised every week from giving away one book per week and don't overthink it you don't have to offer lots of stuff again just one book do you have merch offer one piece of your merch in a giveaway like something connected to whatever your channel is that little incentive might be the thing that pushes people over the edge to giving more and with a giveaway rather than selling something to generate profit you encourage people to donate as much as they are able I put a low minimum six bucks to enter right but most people donate more around 10 20 dollars and then there's some people who will donate 500 or 1 thousand dollars it's not hard to manage I set up a separate email account for it I have people send me screenshots of their donation receipts and once a week I use a random number generator to pick the winner then I get my butt down to the post office and send them off their gift one reason I think people are hesitant to do this is it seems like self promotion and maybe it is a little bit but it's very effective cause your followers want what you have to offer there's a ton of followers I follow where I'd love to get their merch but I'm not gonna just buy it for myself cause I'm on a budget but if I can donate to a good cause feel good about myself and maybe win something  somehow that's like so much more fun and I'm so much more likely to do it and finally and most importantly it is our job to keep hope alive this doesn't mean we can't be real and authentic about our emotions two days ago I made a video sobbing my eyes out about what's happening in Rafa but we have to keep heart and we have to keep going and lead the way as influencers when Okcar Schindler risked his life to save 1,300 Jews from the not sees he had no guarantees that they were going to be able to get out there were over 26,000 Europeans who sheltered Jews during the Holocaust of the 1940s and they didn't have any guarantee that the people living in their attic or basement that they were feeding daily that they were risking their lives and their families lives by sheltering they had no guarantee that the not see regime would ever fall they had no guarantee these people would ever be able to get out and we influencers are not having to risk our lives to help people of Gaza we're just having to make content consistently for them in the wrecked cyberpunk dystopia of this holocaust the pathway out of genus side involves tricking TikTok algorithms and making engaging content starting fake arguments in the comments of fundraiser videos so that we can generate more traction and we can do this I believe in us we can keep hope alive no matter what the it’s really arm y does no matter what horrors come in the coming days and months we are not gonna stop trying to help these families speaking of which I'm helping these sweet kiddos this week and if you learned something useful from this video or appreciated it I'm asking you to donate to their fundraiser and you can enter to win a signed copy hardcover copy of my book Baby Heba here is just five days younger than my baby which makes me feel incredibly connected to her and her dad has been handwriting over 1,000 thank you notes individualized to everyone who's donated to this fundraiser that is not an automated response to help them and enter this week's giveaway go to the first link in my bio donate at least $6 but as much as you are able and send a screenshot of your receipt to T4Gaza at Gmail dot com and to every creator out there who is trying to fundraise for these families in Gaza whether you're able to raise tens of thousand or tens of dollars you are amazing you are my mishpocha  I love you

hey there this is Thomas Emry  Author of the thriller Shrapnel and Avalanches One thing I have noticed recently by talking with other authors is I love the behind the scenes like stories and little tidbits about how everything came to fruition so I wanted to start a thing stitch this and share five facts about your novel or series that people may not know here's mine First, the city of Torwood, Oh  is a kind of fake city but it's a mashup of Toledo Oregon Northwood where I am from The character of Chelsea Winters is heavily influenced by Gail Weathers from Scream right down to the name For the cover I knew I wanted it to be just an an unnamed person holding the mask of the movement, called Instant Karma but I wanted the person unidentified because that's kind of their whole thing as they see themselves as one cohesive unit and not as individual people when they're wearing the masks and doing their doing their thing but it is a character in the book that I put on there um If there's any guesses about who it is let me know. There's a couple lines of dialogue in the book that my editor said to just get rid of cause it doesn't sound like anything anyone would ever say but those are actually the only lines that were taken from actual conversations that I've had in real life so they stayed And lastly I knew while I was writing this what my next story was going to be and I thought about putting a little Easter egg in there um if you don't know the story that I'm working on now is about a child who goes to a sleepover and disappears in the middle of the night but I was going to have Seth who's your main point of view character watching the news and one thing that they report on is a child who went missing in a nearby town in the end I decided that I didn't want to open myself up to plotholes and fact checking type stuff right off the bed as I'm just trying to get a few stories out there so I got rid of it yeah that is five things you might not have known about my novel Shrapnel and Avalanches stitch this and tell me some cool stuff about your book.

let's talk about queer and African spirituality and the special place that queer people hold in Dagara spirituality specifically the Dagara people are a community in Burkina Faso West Africa they do not assign gendor based on anatomy but based on energy the Dagara believe that there are specific gateways on the earth that allow access between the physical and the metaphysical realms and that maintenance of these gates is essential to balance on the earth the people responsible for maintaining these gates are known as gatekeepers which is the dagara term for queer people the dagara believe that queer people with their unique blend of masculine and feminine energies and their ability to sit on the border of the two vibrate at a higher spiritual level that gives them access to and control of these gates the dagara not only believe that queer people's maintenance of these gates keep the world in order but they also believe that the targeting of queer people in recent times will lead to inevitable ecological disaster if you don't know me I'm Wunmi Aramiji I'm a writer and storyteller my debut novel The Waning which is a fantasy based on feminist and non western spirituality is coming out on July 1st this year

what we read shapes us! #booktok #childrensbook #childrenbooks #middlegradebooks #thehungergames #percyjackson #holes #batman #jasontodd #readingispolitical
voice_to_text: these are the books that I read as a child that radicalised me or if not radicalised me then at least definitely shaped my political worldview um and shaped my beliefs as an adult this video idea came to me in a dream um but I figured it would be a fun thing to do and also to discuss how books are political no matter what the book even children's books are political most of these are probably not gonna be surprising but I wanted to talk about them anyway perhaps the least shocking title on this list we have The Hunger Games by Suzanne Collins I read this book when I was 12 I wanna say um maybe 13 and the I think it's pretty self explanatory as to how it can shape political views the concept of children participating in a death game is not a new concept uh most famously and perhaps first I'm not sure it was done in Battle Royale which is a Japanese movie but something that Suzanne Collins I think did here is one brought it to the western world cause a lot of people in the west um were not exposed to Battle Royale but also there is an element of celebrity and glamour to it that um I think these those other death games are kind of lacking the fact that Katniss and Peeta and all the other tributes are considered as celebrities and are given this opulence and wealth when they are being put into a death game is really like cognitive dissonance and I know that Suzanne Collins said that she was inspired to write the book after flicking between um like celebrity gossip footage and footage of um people dying in the Iraq war so I think this one's pretty self explanatory next another non shocker I think I have the Percy Jackson series I'm also including the heroes of Olympus series when I talk about this but the Percy Jackson series really is about a young kid fighting up against oppression against the status quo and how that status quo does not work for anyone [except the elites] um and how he wants to change it and adapt and benefit everyone I remember reading uh the fifth book I think when I was like 10 or 11 or whenever it came out and I remember thinking to myself oh my God I wish I could be a hero like this I wish I could fight and I remember thinking okay I guess the closest thing would be um joining the army and that sounded less fun to me than and less uh enticing than the just cause I wonder I wonder why that is I think I read holes for the first time in third grade I definitely saw the movie around that time definite as well and it taught me about um false imprisonments and the injustices of the correctional system you know this is a forced labour camp that should be illegal and yet it is it's legal in this world and in our world as well it also you know has whole discussions about race inequality with uh the kissing Kate Barlow backstory just brought a lot of themes to my consciousness in elementary school that I was not aware of um and every time I think back about it I'm like yeah damn that book was metal as fuck for a children's book I don't think this one's technically a children's novel but I did read it as a kid and that is Batman oh it's shiny Batman a death in the family this is the famous Batman comic where um everyone could vote on whether or not like people in the public in the 80s could vote on whether or not Jason Todd was going to live or die and they chose for him to die this is probably one of the first times I ever saw a main character die in media that I was consuming but also what's so fascinating about Jason Todd's story is the fact that all of the adults in his life consistently failed him um and so the death in the family and then the subsequent Red Hood saga where Jason comes back and he's a vigilante was very interesting to me and it you know taught me to kind of take everything adults told me with a grain of salt and to maybe think critically about it and then last one as much as I really do dislike admitting this um because it is the year 2024 and I do not think we should be promoting this book whatsoever but I did read it as a child and I do think that the H*rry P*tter series did um lead to a lot of my political ideas especially since the general plot of it is that uh it is someone uprising over a dictatorship it has now radicalized me in a different way because JK R*wling went so far off the fucking deep end in her TERF rhetoric that now I'm radically here to defend trans people and to condemn her so I guess it still radicalized me in another way um but I would be lying if I did not talk about its impact on me as a child and how the idea of um a dictatorship military being overthrown by school age kids was very interesting to me I think it's important to remember that pretty much everything we consume is political even if you don't think it is and that's why I wanna talk about these books that are predominantly for children again the Batman comic I think actually it was technically for adults and I was just reading it uh but these are things that are primarily for children and they have such strong political themes and they still shaped who I am twenty five years later and I think it's very interesting and and relevant to talk about and I would love to know what books you read as a kid that also radicalized you and shaped your political ideologies

voice_to_text: you know what the worst part about X men 97 is it's not the animation or plot holes or the pacing of the show it's not a disrespect for the source material no it's how few people are watching the show it's how few people are witnessing one of the best entries into the Marvel Cinematic Universe that we have gotten since Iron Man truly this show is up there with Infinity War Captain America Winter Soldier Loki season 1 and Loki season 2 Thor Ragnarok and Guardians of the galaxy all of which are some of my favourite MCU projects to date I think this chart speak to some even bigger issues that Disney is having with its biggest IPS namely Marvel and Star Wars just as one example Loki Season 2 for me is one of the most brilliant pieces of Marvel content that we have ever gotten I absolutely love that show and I especially absolutely love season 2 so how is it that this few people watched the show it's the one that's in the light red pink colour x men 97 may not be as low as Loki season 2 but it is still nowhere near where it should be it is still nowhere near the viewership numbers that the beginning of Phase 4 had on Disney plus it's just very sad to see and it's a result of having multiple years of Marvel projects that were sub par and very divisive amongst the fans I hope that we can turn this around because I don't want this to send the wrong message to Disney and I want more people to be able to watch love and appreciate this show

video_description: Ooof I rambled in this one… #booktok #burnout #whatisbooktok #booktokcommunity
voice_to_text: so I haven't posted in like a whole week which is pretty unusual for me because ever since I started this account about 5 months ago I've been posting multiple times a day and honestly I think that took a toll on me because I became very very burnt out and it got to the point where I was pretty obsessed I was posting multiple times a day to maximize my views and my engagement which I think is pretty normal you know we all want our videos to be seen and people to engage with it but it just got to be too much and it got to the point where I was putting more effort and energy into booktok than I was into other areas of my life that really needed it and I just think I needed to step away and find the right balance between booktok and my real life I think the real breaking point came late one night I had not posted that day I don't remember why I didn't but for some reason I didn't post the entire day and it was like getting to be like almost midnight and I was incredibly anxious I thought that TikTok would just shadow ban me no one would see my stuff but then there was another part of me that said you know just relax and post tomorrow and that video did pretty good it didn't crash and burn it didn't get like two views like I thought it would and honestly I was really relieved because it did okay and then I thought why do I even care in the first place and then after that I didn't post for a day and then another day and then another day and I think I got addicted to not posting and I started to kind of think you know what I was doing this all for because before Book Talk I never really posted on a platform regularly like this before with the exception of I guess Facebook a long long time ago but before Booktok  I was really a passive observer and all these other platforms I definitely wouldn't post and I wouldn't even comment and I think that anxiety of being perceived has kind of followed me here to booktok now  I'm sure I'm not alone on that as well I bet a lot of people are anxious about posting because it's kind of scary isn't it and sometimes I feel like you know like why do people care not necessarily about me but like what I have to say on certain things and I guess I just need to get out of my head on that one I don't know even this right now I'm like what am I doing like what is this but what I wanna say is I'm not gonna take bookstok too seriously I'm gonna continue to post but I don't think I'm gonna post every single day um I kind of wanna post with more intention rather than just posting to post and I'm never gonna leave unless they tear down this app because I love this booktok community so much I love all the book recommendations and the real connections I've made on here and I love to make you guys laugh and I love it when you guys make me laugh too so I'm back and watch out

voice_to_text: It's my birthday today. Another year older,   my   birthday   today   Another   year   older another year wiser. But as I sit here surrounded by passing time,   year   wiser   But   as   I   sit   here   surrounded   by   passing   time I can't help but wonder about age and what it truly means.   can't   help   but   wonder   about   age   and   what   it   truly   means Birthdays used to be about cake and presents,   used   to   be   about   cake   and   presents laughter and joy. But as I've grown older,   and   joy   But   as   I've   grown   older I've come to realize   come   to   realize that age isn't just about adding another number to your years.   age   isn't   just   about   adding   another   number   to   your   years It's about the experiences that shape you,   about   the   experiences   that   shape   you the lessons that mold you,   lessons   that   mold   you and the moments that define you.   the   moments   that   define   you And what defines us today is our humanity,   what   defines   us   today   is   our   humanity our actions towards this failing world.   actions   towards   this   failing   world I think about the children of Palestine and Gaza   think   about   the   children   of   Palestine   and   Gaza who may never get the chance to celebrate their birthdays.   may   never   get   the   chance   to   celebrate   their   birthdays I think about the strong and fierce mothers   think   about   the   strong   and   fierce   mothers who never got the chance to give birth.   never   got   the   chance   to   give   birth I think about childhood stolen by cruelty and pure innocence   think   about   childhood   stolen   by   cruelty   and   pure   innocence shattered by violence. voice_to_text: I've been reading hockey romance again, and, you know, every time there's a scene where, like, the star player notices the girl in the crowd, I just kind of think, like, maybe. Like, maybe that's possible. But you know what could be possible? The backup goalie sitting bored as hell at the end, sometimes literally in the crowd. Like, they don't have a spot for the backup goalie, and he's just sitting amongst the fans. What is he doing? He's right there. Like, he's right there begging to be the main character. He's just sitting there eating candy that he stuffed into his pads. You know what? Just singing along to whatever songs playing, just praying he doesn't get thrown in the last five minutes. What about him? I bet he has some games that he plays, even where he scans the crowd looking for people. I bet he makes up, like, entire background stories for the people he sees in the crowd. And then what happens when, like, he spots, like, the girl he used to love, but, like, they tragically had to split up because she went away to college or something? Or, like, what happens when he sees this really cute girl in the crowd and he's like, oh, my goodness. But then he sees this guy walking to a scene. This guy sits down beside her, and they start talking. He's like, oh, my god, she's got a boyfriend. And then it turns out that guy Was, like, just her brother or something. So he, like, writes his name on a puck and tosses it to her. Please think about the backup goalie, okay? He deserves some time, not only on the ice, but in our pages.

Every time I read a romance about a mad, bad, and dangerous to know guy who gets loveified by a seemingly ordinary, yet surprisingly stubborn and fearless woman who refuses to take Nery of his crap, I think of that meme about white women and pit bulls. It's like, honey, your boyfriend has some issues. And she's like, yes, he's a rescue. We're working through it. He, like, slams a stranger against the wall for no reason, and she's like, I'm so sorry. He hasn't been properly socialized yet. He does something, like, explosively violent, and then turns to her, thinking she's going to be horrified, and she's just like, yes, yes, you're very scary. Now, who wants cuddles

Scientists are now warning that there's a giant invasive juro spider with 6 foot webs that could be poised to take over US cities. So fun. Thank you. If you don't know what a Zorro spider is, they're basically a species of orb weaving spiders, which is a group known for creating highly symmetrical circular webs. Cute. Also saying that your host spiders can build unique webs that could be more than 6 feet long and appear golden when they reflect sunlight. Okay, just to make this a little bit better for you, whenever the eggs hatch in spring, the baby spiders create parachute like webs that enable them to fly up to 100 miles away from where they were born. Doro spiders are actually supposed to be in Asia, but they were recently found in Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and China. Then by the way, experts are believing that these invasive individuals were accidentally brought to the US inside a shipping container. So as of right now, these spiders have been spotted in Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina, and Tennessee. And they've also been spotted in Alabama, Maryland, Oklahoma, and West Virginia. I think we reach for SA as a plot device automatically -- it's something on our minds, and it's something we see in a lotttt of SFF because of the history of the genre. But it's time to really start interrogating where, when, how, and why it gets put into our work -- especially when our work takes place in a world that isn't our own. #tipsfromaneditor #writingtips #writingadvice #amwriting #amwritingfantasy #lgbtwriter #queerbooks #indiebooktok #writingabook #authorsofbooktok #indieauthor #iwroteabook #booklover #writertok #fantasybooks #fantasyromance
voice_to_text: Current discussion of the 4B movement has me thinking a lot about how we center men in fiction. To that end, I wanna talk about sexual violence against women in second world fantasy. Usually when I see sexual violence used against women in these contexts, it serves one or two purposes, sometimes both at the same time. The first is to clue the reader in that the man who perpetrated that assault or that attempted assault is bad. It's a moral event horizon. Once a character crosses that moral event horizon, they're irredeemably evil. Or, and related. It gives the good guys, so the good male character, an opportunity to rescue the woman from sexual violence. These are extremely common tropes. I see them all the time. Quite literally, they use sexual violence against women as a way to characterize men, positively or negatively. This centers men in what are often women stories in which sometimes the sole or primary point of view character is a woman. Which is an interesting choice. Do we think perhaps if we realize that we are using sexual violence in order to characterize a male character or set up a plot event for that male character, perhaps we could reach for something else, some other trope that does not rely on the victimization of a woman? Just food for thought.

video_description: feeling v emo tbh!! over $160k for Palestinian families trying to get to safety 😭❤️ #satrayreads #bookishcommunity #booktokfyp #booktok #gazabookauction
voice_to_text: hi friends so last night the Gaza book auction ended and look how much money we raised so this amount that I'm gonna show you is not the final amount because we still need to account for the donations of people who donated but didn't bid who were out bid but donated anyways people are matching donations like the donors are matching donations and we also have donors who offered up additional items for the second highest bidder and things like that so this is just for the auction items and on the auction items alone we raised $160,259 what I truly have no word like this is unreal the entire point of this auction was like how can we get funds directly into the hands of Palestinians on the ground who are in need of support and as we are going through verifying the donations we are watching in real time gofundme goals getting closer and closer to being met we have people donating more than the item that they won we have people who were like I didn't win but here's my donation we have people who were like I wasn't even trying to win but here's my donation and what this auction has really shown me is a few thing one we are already all equipped with all of the tools that we need to collectively fight for liberation and to collectively care for each other this option came together because our friend lean was like I wanna do this thing and we were like okay let's mobilize our network and let's utilize our different skill sets to make this happen this auction is the product of five people being like we have time we have skills we have a network we have platforms let's mobilize our community and then our community showed up if you build it people will come and I think for me that's one of the biggest lessons right like we don't have to wait for someone else to like build the thing we can build it ourselves and people will show up so yeah I guess what I'm trying to say is like we already all have the power within us to collectively move everyone towards liberation just a matter of identifying like where am I most useful what can I do with the things that I have with the abilities that I have with the privileges that I have to do something for the collective and then doing the thing so yeah I'm just super grateful for Leen and all of the other organisers for the Gaza Book Auction I'm super grateful for every single person who donated um an item for the auction every single person who bid every single person who donated to Gofundmes every single person who spread the word I am just super grateful that our community showed up the way that it did for folks who are trying to get to survival and safety

video_description: Does anyone else remember what happened the last time a Bridgerton made a secret alliance? 😏 Here's an EXCLUSIVE look at #NicolaCoughlan and #LukeNewton in #Bridgerton Season 3.
voice_to_text: I'm not the man I was last season, and I'm most certainly not ashamed of you, Penn. The opposite is true. In fact, I seek you out at every social assembly because I know you will lift my spirits and make me see the world in ways I could not have imagined. You are clever and warm, and I am proud to call you my very good friend. Just been vexing watching you walk back into society with such ease. But every year I pray I might finally feel that way amidst the marriage mart, and that comfort never materializes. Well, if a husband is what you seek, let me help you. Help me how? I was in 17 cities this summer, and what I have Learned is that charm can be taught. I cannot have you with me whispering into my ear in every ballroom. You will not need that. We will have lessons, and you will quickly master them, I'm certain.

I remember when I was looking up how much money that the United States sends to Israel every year, a list came up that showed, like, every country that we send money to, and Egypt was, like, really high on the list. For Egypt, one of the benefits of the treaty was a warmer relation with the United States. To a degree, at least. The United States bought the peace treaty by promising both Israel and Egypt enormous aid packages. By September, US aid totaled 4.3 billion. Cashing in on his new friendship with the United States, he submitted several military shopping lists that called for expenditures of many billions of dollars. And on the page before this, um, it says, Carter was praised by both Middle Eastern leaders, but particularly by President Sadat. I think that's how you say his name. Um, who is the Egyptian president who said that without the American president's efforts, There would have been no treaty. “Look, the average income in my district is $55,000 a year. A congressman makes $174,000 a year,” says Representative Larry Buschon. Though outgoing members of Congress acknowledged the bad optics of voting to raise their own salaries, they also pointed out the difficulty of maintaining a dual presence in both Washington and their home district. “I’m trying to maintain two places to live, have clothes in two places, have a car in two places. It’s very difficult,” says Representative Ken Buck. “Do you want it to still be the house of the people?” asks Representative Anna Eshoo. “Or do you want it to be only wealthy people?” #congress #nytopinion

I cannot stress enough how important it is for women, especially young women, to love themselves in a world that's constantly conditioning you to hate yourself. And this goes beyond simply just thinking you're pretty. Like, loving yourself is more than just thinking, oh, I'm cute and my body is tea. Of course you should find yourself attractive. That's amazing. It's so much deeper than that. Loving yourself is about how you show up for yourself every single day. It's about how you advocate for yourself in uncomfortable situations. It's about the type of people you choose to date. It's about the type of friends you keep. It's about the habits you have. It's about what you choose to tolerate in your life. It's about how you let other people treat you. Finding yourself attractive is only a very small portion of loving yourself. That's why there's so many people who are beautiful, but they hate themselves. Because it's more than just thinking that you're pretty. I really want women specifically to experience what it's like to love yourself beyond your physical appearance, because it's going to change the quality of your life.

What do you think about prologues and epilogues? #booktok #writersoftiktok #reader #readersoftiktok
voice_to_text: Prologues and epilogues. What do you, as a reader and/or writer, think about either? I've heard a lot of people dislike prologues. A lot of people skip prologues, which isn't even a thing I ever thought of as an option. I- if it's there, I read it. I've never thought critically about them until joining BookTok, but what do you think about them? As for epilogues, I haven't seen quite as much controversy with them. For me, my current story, The Shield, has both a prologue and an epilogue. The prologue as it currently stands, and I'm not sure I'm keeping it, is to show a glimpse into the past that is almost impossible to show in any other way. Maybe I could do some sort of flashback or something, but I didn't really like those as a reader. And then the epilogue is to set up a potential book two. But what do you think about prologues and epilogues?

video_description: Replying to @ur_aicy knowing where your story starts can be super difficult, especially when you're writing multiple narrative threads! hopefully this helps you figure out where to get started. 😊 #writingadvice #babyauthor
voice_to_text: where do you begin your book this is a really good question and what I generally like to tell my writers is start your book as close to the end as you possibly can what do I mean by that I mean don't get bogged down in backstory narratives by nature are ultimately vehicles of conflict and change and transition so when you're starting your story you should start as close to that transition as possible while still showing us enough of their life before it so that we understand the change that's happening in Joseph Campbell's Heroes journey this is called the Ordinary World and it's Bilbo's birthday party at the Shire before anything starts or it's Lizzie Bennett and her sisters getting ready for a ball before she meets Mr Darcy it's there to show us what normal life is like before the story comes on in and turns everything upside down on its head the trick with the ordinary world is you wanna put in just the right amount of it you wanna show the readers enough to give them a sense of here's who the characters are what their lives are like but not so much that they get bored before you throw in the hook that call to adventure or that catalyst in a very specific case like the original commenter's book which contains more than one timeline it might mean getting a little wibbly wobbly and creative with how you present this stuff remember that books do not have to be told chronologically if that doesn't serve the story choose one storyline to be your main storyline which in this case sounds like it would be the storyline when your characters are adults and use that secondary storyline of when they're younger to kind of weave it in and provide context when necessary you can do this with flashback scenes kind of alternating back and forth with then and now or you could honestly just allude to things that happened in the past and use that main storyline as the strong beat that readers follow throughout there's a million ways to do this and honestly I work with a lot of writers who just start writing figure out what they wanna do and edit it later so biggest piece of advice for first time writers just start writing just get it out there just do it um you can always fix it in editing and in the meantime you're learning you're building your skills as you go you got this

voice_to_text: I'm a diagnosed psychopath and these are some of the special interests I had when I was a kid we're gonna start off with a bang I was really into the Holocaust specifically when I was a kid not really World War 2 as a whole but specifically the Holocaust when I was in the third grade we had a book fair at school and I remember seeing this little black book called the Holocaust and being really intrigued by it so I went picked it up started reading it and ended up sitting an hour at the book fair reading this book under the table after that I was so fascinated by the subject and even when I was in eighth grade and I went on my DC trip I opted to go to the Holocaust Museum over the Smithsonian my second special interest which might not be a shock after that first one is I was really into Grimm fairy tales like the original Grimm fairy tales I had a massive book with all the fairy tales in it and if you guys don't know what the Grimm fairy tales are they are the original fairy tales and they're extremely morbid they're not very PG like the fairy tales we learn now but I was really obsessed with that book I read it all the time there was also a movie I believe it's called Grimm that I really loved when I was a kid it's about the Grimm brothers fighting this witch that sucking the youth out of all the young girls in this village but yeah I was really into grim fairy tales when I was a kid my next special interest slightly going off with that was the Romanov family if you guys aren't familiar with the Romanov family it's Tsar Nicholas the second of Russia and his family most famously Anastasia and Rasputin whom most people probably know from the song but he was a real person he was the lover of the Russian queen but yeah the entire Romanov family was murdered Rasputin was poisoned but he survived the poisoning Anastasia was presumed dead but her body was never found so a lot of people thought that she escaped and she grew up somewhere else it's a really again morbid but fascinating story and the reason I got into this was in the fourth grade we had to do an autobiography on somebody and I picked Anastasia and after that I was really invested in her history and going off of more book type things the next interest I had was Greek mythology I grew up in the Percy Jackson era so naturally I was really into Greek mythology just like a lot of kids my age but again I had several books full of Greek myths and back then I could tell you everything about every god or demigod and specifically I was really intrigued by the labyrinth and a lot of things that adapted the labyrinth and in case you guys didn't know The Hunger Games was slightly based on the labyrinth the idea of putting kids into an arena where they die which is what the idea of the labyrinth was you put people in there and they could never escape and the last special interests I'll talk about today is the Aztec and Mayan empires it shouldn't be a shock to you guys that I was really really intrigued by the whole human sacrifice thing and actually recently I was in Mexico and I did get to visit Chichen Itza it's this whole sacred city with the big temple where they performed the sacrifices and it was honestly so surreal I really enjoyed that experience that's all for this video today if you guys don't know me I'm Vic and I'm a diagnose psychopath and I talk about being a psychopath on my page so if you're interested in that you can go ahead and follow along if you have any questions go ahead and leave them in the comments and thanks for watching

MET GALA 2024: Garden of Time  @Marc Bouwer & I wanted to capture the elegance of the 1600s/1700s period of fashion (& my obsession with Bridgerton) while also exploring different textures of glass, crystal, and florals. The Met Gala 2024 theme was named after "The Garden of Time" - a short story by J.G Ballard. Since the story has melenchaly elements, Marc chose to make the gown in soft, almost moody colors. 🫶🏻 #MetGala2024

voice_to_text: let them eat cake you see now I wasn't even gonna make any content about the Met Gala because I know a lot of people use the Met Gala as a time to talk about fashion and art and they use it as a moment of levity in their lives trust me in the times we're getting in I get it however pairing that look with this sound at that event we need to talk about it the startling juxtaposition of having an extremely extravagant ball where only the wealthiest people can even attend side by side with the suffering that we see regularly is baffling like the idea of paying $75,000 for a one ticket to attend this event while most people don't even make that much money in a year combined with the criminalization of homelessness the basic essentials in the grocery store are priced out of a lot of people's price points that mere healthcare is unattainable that public education is being defunded people are outraged as they should be so to pair that with the ostentatiousness of a Met Gala is surmised in this video remember where that phrase comes from let them eat cake reflects a flipping attitude of the aristocracy to the suffering of the common people and when people couldn't afford to buy a basic essential as bread that the aristocracy was just like all right we'll let them eat cake it shows the massive disconnect which is further illustrated by the ostentatiousness of this ball I'm down for fashion I'm down for fun I love this stuff but what was absolutely gross to me was this awareness of the suffering of other people to pair your Met Gala look with this sound and to essentially say well I'm sorry you're suffering but I'm out here having a great time make it make sense

So obviously she's posting a lot and frequently on her Facebook page, so I'll keep you guys updated. This is another video that I found on her page, and it's basically just her telling the dads of the kids that they're at CPS and if they want them to come and get them because she's about to give them to CPS. So that's. This video was at the firehouse for two hours, but we're here at Children's Services now. If there's any family out there on my case, dad's side. I don't have nobody's contact information. voice_to_text: Ninety nine percent of the comments we receive online are wonderful. People sharing their own stories of ADHD woes, realizing for the first time that they might have ADHD, and genuinely experiencing the I thought it was just me shock. But then there's the remaining 1%, the negative comments, which are very creative and cover a range of topics. I remind myself that people leaving hateful comments probably aren't living the happiest lives themselves, and I simply block and delete. Just because somebody shares a harmful opinion doesn't mean that we have to engage with it. Your struggles, your story, your voice, your experience. These things cannot be invalidated by anyone. Not by user 9 9. 6. 4. 4. 5 shouting into the social media void that ADHD is just an excuse for being lazy. We adhders are here. We have wet laundry in the dryer, we have thousand unread texts, and we are trying to stop hating ourselves. Nothing anyone says stops us from existing or stops our symptoms from being very real.

Fantasies and I am not a full time author I have a full time job so I work for a construction company doing design and budgeting and so that fills up all my days and then evenings and afternoons are filled up with kids I have a three and a half year old and a five and a half year old and they have busy activities and my wife works a part time job and has other things going on that means I don't get time for myself to write until after the kids are in bed which I would love it to be earlier but it's usually between 8 and 8:45 but I've just set a standard time uh for myself that is my time to go right and that's 9 about nine PM after the kids are in bed I right now I have pulled back a little bit and so like my wife and I have a night just for ourselves and then Tuesday nights are my lives and so typically I haven't been doing any writing then and you have the occasional things pop up but three to five days a week I try to write from nine PM to eleven PM if I can make it sometimes it's gone longer on the midnight to depending on where I'm at in the flow state and if I if the words are coming then I'm not putting a stop to it if I can if I can go a little further that's kind of how I've overcome writer's block I haven't really experienced writer's block I'm kinda constantly thinking about the book and what I wanna write and when I sit down I haven't really had a moment where I struggled with words to put on the page and so I don't have great advice for anyone on that I just uh I just do it which I know is terrible nobody wants to hear that just sit down and do it but that's what I do I just sit down and I do it and if I am struggling a little bit with a scene or or or how to word something I will just go ahead and just write something terrible I'll just write anything I can I'll put things in brackets I'll just throw stupid stuff in there and make a note to come back and correct it when I am feeling a little fresher and feel like I can actually make the writing a little better but I know everyone is different so I'm a little more aware and awake at night and that's the only time I have so I've set that time aside and that's when I do it and I just kind of allow myself to do it poorly when I need to but I've really found my passion for writing now and so it's just something I really I love doing I just love sitting down and getting the world and the words on paper and so it's not hard for me to want to do that I also come from a theater background a technical theater background and so I'm very uh used to this kind of fast paced process and the drafting process and building on ideas and I've been writing uh things you know for a lot of my life uh and a lot of academic papers and dread and you know design briefs and things like that and so a lot of that has kind of helped transfer over I can talk about that field another time but those kind of skills and that uh mindset that I had to get in for Gram School and other things have kind of helped and I've also written screenplays and and some small plays for for the stage and so that has helped with dialogue and I've Learned a lot there oh anyways like I said everybody's gonna be a little bit different you might be a morning person you might be an afternoon person you might have more time to kinda devote to smaller chunks uh I have been trying some writing sprints lately just to kinda freshen things up a bit and those have been going pretty well uh but for me it's just a matter of setting the time sitting down and doing it for a set amount of time and having a word count that I'd like to try to meet in an overall goal and if I'm struggling a little bit take a deep breath and then just write something poorly and let it get on paper

With the edits done and the book all but ready, it’s an exciting thing to look forward into the “what’s next?” If it all.  If you know you are a writer, I hope you write your story—and don’t let anything sway you from it. ❤️ #authorsoftiktok #writing #publishing
voice_to_text: When the year 2,022 started, I did not know it was going to be the year that I finally wrote a book. I had found a quote by Brett Goldstein about being like a muppet that it sort of cracked my heart open. Then I read Big Magic by Elizabeth Gilbert. That book right there that convinced me that you don't have to be good at something. You don't have to be perfect at it. It doesn't have to be the best thing that's ever existed. And in order for it to be worthy of you creating it. Few months into the year, I decided I was going to start writing every day. Just anything, even if it was. I'm writing today because I promised myself I would write soon enough. The book started coming New Year's Eve last year, like 2:00 o'clock in the morning. Before I went to bed, I finished the book. If there is something in you that says you are supposed to write, even if you've never been able to get more than a few pages, you need to be writing. Don't let your fear or insecurity or feeling like you're not good enough stop you. Because the best thing I've ever experienced was living into the truth that I'm a writer and that there was a story inside me bursting to get out. And however this coming year ends up unfolding, when the book releases, the dream has come true. I wanted to write a Book all my life. And now I have, and I hope you do too.
