voice_to_text: book marketing I've been asked many times about the best ways to market self publish and indie published books  I'm the wrong person to ask I literally don't market my books properly I'm incapable of it  you see all the videos out there of people with their books going here this is my book and it is about this and you would love this please buy my book  they don't sound like that but still  I can't do that  I can't push my own books  yesterday I published an 'on this day' video from a year ago  which was a marketing video for The Dead Woods one of my books (BUY IT) and it basically was my first step into developing my marketing voice if you will...  which is not serious I mean I write horror and dark fantasy so they're quite serious book sometimes but I can't sit there and seriously go this is my book please buy my book  I literally have to make a joke out of it  and that's kind of my style now and I like to think it is like anti marketing because I'm not marketing the product I'm basically more or less marketing of my brand um and just whatever book I'm holding at the time is interchangeable and doesn't really matter so I'm the wrong person to ask how to market really my only advice is just try and make marketing materials whether videos, posts or whatever that would make you buy a book personally yeah that's my marketing suggestions I'm terrible at this

voice_to_text: so it's my understanding that there is a current ongoing discourse about authors writing quickly and I feel qualified to speak on this because I am 26 years old and I have written and published somewhere over 30 books I started writing consistently when I was about 19 took me a year to write my first book which did nothing because I didn't have any skills yet and favorite though really does many people love it a lot of people hate it second book took me about six months to write and on my third book I was hanging out in writer spheres around this time and I heard advice that was to write 2,000 words a day write every day it was Stephen King's advice in the following month I wrote the sequel to my first book and it came out to roughly 125,000 words in less than 30 days and I fucking love this book it's a fan favorite of a lot of my readers this is the horse that created us everybody who's read the Loading Destiny series agrees that it is amazing book if not very depressing continue writing at this pace of an average of 3,333 words a day for about four years why that number I don't know that's just always what an averaged out to hopefully makeup doesn't come out all kinds of fucked up so I'm doing it for my iPhone anyway fast forward to the year 2022 that's when I write Raven's Cry that book also took me a little bit more than a month to write so it's write it around 100,000 words really didn't require much editing either not content wise maybe some grammar and stuff but I didn't change much when the book was done graph that is still out is pretty close to the one that I originally wrote fast forward to 2023 by chance I come across a really popular mystery thriller author who agrees to co write with me I already had a few five figure months working with him I'm up to consistent five figure months it's like 60 to 90% read through on all of my series meaning people who read book one go on to read the later books I don't know 60 to 90% people don't think that they're bad even though they're written quick the important half of this story is that I developed repetitive strain injuries couldn't type and had to slow down I'm now writing about a book every two months and granted I have now adjusted to dictation which is certainly helped but take today for instance I wrote about 15 words and then my throat was sore and I had to stop creatively I know how the rest of this book is gonna go I could write the 20,000 words in a day if my body would let me and by readers would love it like they have loved every other book but I have written quickly the hard part though as a writer is that that story is inside of me and it once on the page what makes it difficult is my body stopping me not the writing itself some of us are just fast writers and if you're that's fine but you're wrong when you say that our book aren't good just because we've written faster than you did

video_description: Replying to @Jo Hope this helps!  Ignore the sounds of my dog faffing around 😂😂 #literaryagent #booktok #queryingauthors #amquerying #publishing
voice_to_text: Let's talk comp titles. Hi, I'm Alice. I'm a literary agent, and I'm answering your querian questions. So first of all, what is a comp title? Well, it's basically a comparison title. It's when you say, my dystopian YA is for fans of The Hunger Games and divergent. And that basically, in a query, tells the agent that you have researched and found out where your book sits on the market. It's a really, really important tool. And every single time somebody has said in their query, I can't find anything that's like my book, I have been able to list a minimum of five titles that they could have comped. It's also not just for querying. Creators, agents use comps. I just sent out a book last week that had three comps. And that's how publishers know where to place the book if they buy it, and basically how much to pay for it. As for the reading question, I honestly don't know why you would be writing in an area that you're not reading in. Um, that is kind of bonkers to me. But, you know, fun little story time. I used to do one to one sessions, and, uh, the number of times somebody would be like, I've written this middle grade historical fantasy, and I'd say, great, do you read middle grade? And they go, no. And I be like, why you here? Why you not reading in the area that you're writing in? You need To know what's working, you need to know what works, need to know what sells. Because at the end of the day, much as your writing is your art, the second that you're trying to get it published, it is then a product. So, yes, I would say it is imperative. And it is very obvious. When somebody isn't reading. In the similar genre for submission. Okay, more to come. Let me know if you have any questions.

voice_to_text: Hello, everyone. As you may know, may is Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month. And this month I'm wanting to really focus on Pacific Islander authors because there's not a lot of them out there, so I really wanna highlight them. And today I wanna talk about SCI fi and fantasy books by Pacific Islander authors. Now, this will be part one out of two, because there are actually a lot of SCI fi fantasy books that I found, and it's just we need to talk about in one video. First up is the Dawn Hounds, and it sounds so, so good. It's like a SCI fi mystery sort of thing. It follows our main character, who is a thief turned cop who ends up being murdered one night, but then she finds out that she's woken up and then gets rescued by, like, pirates. There's also, like, an evil plague, queer representation and cool powers, and it just sounds like such an interesting book. And I believe that the second book comes out this year. Next up is the upwelling, which I believe follows three main characters and includes time travel and also has Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander folklore. One of our main characters is having visions about the end of the world, and there's two warring spirits which are possibly going to be the cause of the end of the world. And at first, no one believes this girl until she finds the two other characters. In this story. I read Dragon Fruit the other week and I loved it. It was so much fun. Dragon Fruit follows our main character Hanale, who returns home to the kingdom that she was born in and grew up in, but she's been living away from it for years because of something horrible that her father had done. Once she arrives back home, she goes on a quest with the Prince Sam to go and find a sea dragon egg. You heard me. This world has sea dragons and they're so cool, they're so interesting. It's beautifully done. But anyways, they're trying to find the sea dragon egg because it has the power to grant one wish, but it comes out of price. Also by Makia Lucier is song of the abyss, which follows our main character Rayna, who is like a navigator and she's returning home from a big year long exposition when her ship is attacked. When she escapes, she finds out that the people that like, attacked her have totally disappeared and vanished. So she ends up having to team up with the king prince, some. Some royal dude from the rival kingdom. And together they discover that there's some sinister things happening from one of the neighbouring kingdoms and they have to figure out what it is. Naviro is a SCI fi novel which follows our main character Tia, whose sister has gone out on like an expedition in space in a spaceship. But that Spaceship gets sucked into some whirlpool thing and goes missing. And so then Tia has to go and traverse the space to try and find and rescue her sister. So yeah, these are just a couple of the fantasy and SCI fi books that I found. And stay tuned for part two so I can tell you about even more of them, cause I am so excited to talk about the rest as well.

what are your favourite parts and least favourite parts about listening to an audiobook I listen to a ton of audiobooks right now I do still read a lot of physical books often times I'll do both at the same time and I've come to love them for sure but there's definitely some drawbacks one of the positives for listening to the audiobook is that I always know how names and towns are pronounced I feel like I don't have to wonder at all about the pronunciation of anything in a book but the con of that is I don't know how any of it is spelled so whenever I'm trying to write in my book love and bring up a character I've only heard about in the audio book I have to go back any of the physical book I have or ebook or googled how to spell some of those names especially in the book we're reading right now the shadow of the gods they have a ton of different Norse styled words in there or Nordic styled words rather and I have no idea how to spell or where the accent marks go on any of these names or places and so I just try to avoid using them at all costs and I'm like yeah that one person doing that one thing and then vice versa with the physical book I know how everything spelled but I've no idea how to pronounce anything and so I'll go maybe my whole life pronouncing something wrong until I running to somebody else who listened to the audiobook or saw something from the author that said oh no this is actually how it's pronounced and then I've got to do this shifting around in my brain of how this stuff work that's just kind of one of the great examples of the give and take to the different mediums but I'd love to hear what you guys love about audio books which you don't enjoy about audio books and whether or not you guys have ever tried doing both at the same time

Raziell is a Dragon. He’s meant to have subtly Draconic features in his humanoid form, which emphasis on subtle. Every time I draw him in his humanoid form, he looks too much like a Dragon. The average bystander doesn’t know Dragons are shifters, and neither do most Hunters. Only the most well-trained Hunters (and oldest, as well) would be able to tell, and they’d have to get exceptionally close to him, close enough to see his eyes.  With how I’ve drawn him before, his heritage is too obvious to me. His pupils too cat-like. His appearance not human enough. Or he has otherwise just not looked like himself.  I want to draw the cover of Scales myself when time comes. I even have a design, but in order to do that, I have to be able to draw him. I wish I knew why I can’t seem to capture his likeness on paper. Sometimes I consider giving up- I’m a writer, after all, not an artist… But I desperately need to draw him. 10 years of not being able to draw my own character correctly is far too long.  The other deuteragonist, a woman named Kalyrah, has a solid design that I’ve been able to consistently draw. I have never once deviated from what she’s meant to look like. I’ve always drawn her the same, but for some reason that has never been true for my Raziell. I am never satisfied with how he ends up on the page. He always looks wrong. He never looks like he should.  #writing #characterdesign #dragon #fantasynovel #scalesnovel #shapeshifter #RaziellofScales #KalyrahofScales #fantasy #novel #dragons #elves #art #characterart #author #writertok #fantasywriter #novelist #aspiringwriter #fantasywriting

video_description: My book is coming up on its first book birthday! And I'm doing a schmivaway! #yafantasy #schmivaway #giveaway #booktok #indiebooktok #yaindiebooks #thewoundsofwisdom
voice_to_text: hello friends so in two days on Tuesday May 7th I will be having my very first anniversary of being a published indie author Yay and my book The Wounds of Wisdom will be celebrating its first birthday so I'm really excited and I asked the folks in my discord server what I should do to celebrate and the most feasible thing that was suggested was a schmivaway so this will be my first schmivaway and I will be giving away two copies of The Wounds of Wisdom they will both be signed so I don't have a lot of qualifications for this one I just kind of wanna share the joy so if you're interested in a copy of a ya fantasy with court intrigue by a debut indie author comment down below let me know I will announce the winner on Tuesday night and then I will start working on getting the books out to you so yeah happy wounds anniversary

video_description: Making this video was actually so fun @kingandqueenlion @ND | Manga Creator #anime #manga #sunwukong #godofhighschool #goku
voice_to_text: a few days ago I made a video explaining  just how powerful Sun Wukong from The Journey to the West is and well the man himself king Lion decided to debunk my video if you can even really  call it a debunk because he didn't debunk anything he just yapped for  almost eight minutes so today I'm gonna go through  every single debunk he made  and explain why he's wrong so in my video the other day the first point I made was  that Sun Wukong solo’d the entire Chinese pantheon all by himself to which King Lion said this scathing absolutely scathing oh and to answer your question yes he did solo the whole pantheon when Sun Wukong ate  every single peach of immortality  in heaven right before  their giant Peach festival the Jade Emperor was  understandably pissed so he sent down  the four great heavenly kings along with Heavenly King Li  and Prince Nezha to mobilize the 28 constellations the 9 bright shiners the 12 gods of the 12 branches the revealers of truth and the five regions the 4 duty gods the constellations of the east and the west the gods of the north and the south the deities of the five mountains and the four rivers the star ministers of all heaven and a total of 100,000 heavenly soldiers that is quite literally every single god and constellation that the Taoist Chinese mythology  has to offer and Sun Wukong soloed all of them so after refusing to address  my first point about Sun Wukong  destroying all of heaven's deities King Lion back pedals to  what about all the fights  that song Sun Wukong lost what about all the times  he got captured and to that I say  if you know anything about  The Journey to the West at all you know that Sun Wukong gets  significantly weaker after being  sealed by the Buddha for 500 years he literally could not  cultivate his taoist superpowers  while trapped under that mountain and after getting out  from under that mountain he gets a cursed crown  placed on his head that limits his abilities even further even then throughout the entirety  of The Journey to the West storyline there is never a moment in time  where Wukong is genuinely in danger unfortunately the monk Tripitaka  is super weak so Wukong  has to be super careful  in all of his fights to make sure Tripitaka  doesn't just die from excess explosions like I said there is never a moment  where Wukong couldn't just bust in and absolutely destroy  everyone he comes across but he has to actually be careful which is part of the theme  of his journey to enlightenment in the first place  to have some self control I also mentioned in my previous video that Wukong jumped all the way  to the edge of the universe during a bet with the Buddha and that was a massive  speed feat for him King Lion then completely ignored the fact that I was  using that interaction for speed feats and then said this yes Wukong did lose that bet but that's not the reason  I brought that interaction up  in the slightest I used it as a speed feat I didn't bring up the fact  that he lost a Buddha because Buddha is not a part  of the Chinese mythology pantheon the Chinese pantheon  like the Jade Emperor  are part of Taoism the Buddha is part of Buddhism they're two different religions the Jade Emperor calling up  the Buddha to handle Wukong is like if Zeus decided to call up  Jesus to handle Kratos so when I say that Wukong solo’d the entirety of the Chinese pantheon I'm not including Buddha  because Buddha is not  a part of that pantheon my final point was that at the end  of the Journey to the West Wukong attains the title of Buddha  after achieving enlightenment meaning he's part of the Dharmakaya making him essentially omnipresent and King Lion then said this this is so simple it's absurd this is quite literally just King Lion not understanding  the book that he is reading the whole reason that Wukong joined Tripitaka on his journey to the west  in the first place was so that he could obtain  true immortality and enlightenment the reason the Buddha Tathagata  grants Wukong the title of  Buddha Victorious in Strife is because he understands that  Wukong has attained enlightenment at this point he's even mentioned  in the Buddhist chants when they're paying homage  to all of the Buddhas in history right here homage to  the Victorious Fighting Buddha so to say that Wukong obtained  an empty title as Buddha and didn't actually attain Nirvana is you just not understanding the text in fact it makes me think that you didn't even read  The Journey to the West in the first place and just skimmed over it for this video because to miss that fact you have to have missed out  on the point of the entire novel to put it simply King Lion has no idea  what he's talking about here and his eight minute yap sesh  was absolutely ridiculous

video_description: HELP ME NOT BE TERRIBLE AT THIS PLEASE!!!! @Sinners&Stardust #sinnersandstardust #sinnersandstardustinfluencer #sinnersandstardustball #darkromancebooks #darkromancereads #darkromanceball
contemplating returning 😭  #kobolibracolour#kobocolor#kobo#ereader#kindleoasis#colorereader#kindlevskobo#libbyapp#netgalley#kindle
voice_to_text: just got my Kobo Libra color in the mail here are my first impressions of somebody that has been using a Kindle Oasis for years just looking at like the shape and the body of the devices they're very similar one thing I prefer about the Kobo is that the back is flat I don't know I just like that more than this little ridge that the Oasis has they both have the page turn buttons the screens are very similar size my only complaint probably about the way the Kobo looks is that on the Kindle Oasis if you have it you know this is all like one screen on the Kobo this there's like a lip right here so the screen is like a layer below this which I don't know there's something about it that I just don't like I did not wanna pay $70 for a Kobo stylus so I bought this like $25 one on Amazon have it linked to my Amazon storefront it does work on the Kobo with some potential caveats I love on the Kobo this feature where you can increase and decrease brightness I don't have any problems with the contrast I know a lot of people were saying that this was something to look out for I can definitely see a bit of a difference when I'm looking out the Kobo and the Oasis like right next to each other but when I'm just reading on this like the contrast seems perfectly fine to me um I don't have a problem with that you can choose your pen size and you can choose your pen color or on this device I have by pressing the button down here I can do just like a regular highlight if I want to write I can just doodle my biggest problems so far just playing around with this annotation one there is no sort of like palm rejection and it could be because I'm not using the Kobo brand stylus I'm not sure but if I want to like write like this everything pops up it just becomes a mess so I have to keep my palm off of the Kobo third thing which again could be because I don't have the Kobo brand stylus is that erasing annotations is a little bit of a pain I can't just like click an annotation and have it delete unfortunately I have to go here I have to go to my annotations I have to find an annotation like this hold it down and then click Remove Markup for that specific one which just like takes kind of longer than I would like however this is something that most other e readers are really not offering at all so I understand it's not going to be perfect and I love the ability to doodle and annotate this um Stylus that I got is also magnetic so it will um stay here or on the side of the Kobo I have also played around a little bit with net galley and like Libby Kindle makes these so easy on net galley you can literally just click send to Kindle and when you send a book to your Kindle from net galley file doesn't expire you can keep it on your Kindle forever with other file types from netgalley if you like download them there is a DRM on it so deadline for when you can read the thing whatever so if you are going to want to use your Kobo to read on netgalley you can but just know that the files will expire they won't be there forever are ways to like get around that but I'm pretty sure it's illegal so I'm not gonna advise you on how to do that you have to download the epub file open it in Adobe Digital Editions and then like plug in your Kobo and send it to the device so definitely a lot more work there then for Libby I was really excited cause I knew Kobo had overdrive integration so you could like browse Libby on your Kobo which you can which is great however the like overdrive app on here it's not as intuitive as like the actual Libby on your phone with your Kindle you can use the Liby app on your phone scroll search do everything you want and then just click send to Kindle and it will just be on your Kindle what I found with Kobo you can't do that you have to like actually download the book from your Kobo a lot of books that are on Liby you are not able to read on Kobo so you can download a book on the Liby app on your phone and then sync your app sync your Kobo but it may or may not show up on here because some of the books will be formatted for Kobo and some will not and I can't find a way on the Liby app to determine which ones can and which ones also you can just have one overdrive account at a time so I had to choose only one library card to connect which is like not ideal I want to love this so much and I'm gonna keep messing around with it a lot of other thoughts so if you guys want more or if you have specific questions let me know so far like I hate to say it but I'm kinda disappointed

voice_to_text: okay I've been seeing a bunch of booktokers post book rec videos based on the challengers movie and all of the book recs are like straight tennis romances I'm gonna be so honest if you left challengers and your first thought was I wanna read a tennis romance and not I wanna read a why choose romance respectfully we were watching two different movies I left that movie theater and my only thoughts were I want two boyfriends and I want them to kiss and I wanna be able to f with their heads a little bit where are those book recs and not one of those weak ass why choose romances either where there's like one girl and six guys and the six guys are all still straight they're like yeah we're all into her but not each other we're not gay like that and I'm like what do you mean not even a little bit just kiss each other honestly it's homophobic at this point for you not be into each other a little bit anyway that's my rant I'm sorry I got a little heated there this is the subject that I care a lot about please give me some why choose romance book recs in the comments if they have tennis in them great but I really don't care also does anyone else get like genuinely ill overseeing bones break in movies cause that scene was Zendaya I literally almost threw up that needed a trigger warning

oh this got me thinking Gen X what was the song that you used to sing as a kid that you had no business no business listening to and you didn't even know what you were singing about I listen to everything I can get my hands on because I just loved music so that included like my dad's old soul records folks talking about turning off the light spending the night in Wonderland all the 90s R&B music and the rock music was no different I I know that I didn't understand what they meant when they said she's my cherry pie but I get it now and all the Prince all the I'm 46 and I listen to some Prince music and I still don't know what he's talking about ah they wonder why we are the way we are

how long are we all giving books before we are dnfing and just calling it quits I have two books I'm about to return to the library and I dnfed both of them I am trying to be better about to dnfing because there's kinda no point pushing all the way through a book if I already get the feeling that I'm not gonna like it but then at the same time I keep thinking but what happens if there's something really good at the end that I end up liking it and I don't get to find out if I dnf’d it um so do you dnf cause I know some people don't and if you do how long do you give the book before you dnf um I'm returning this one which neither of these books it was not their fault it was definitely just the book wasn't for me but The Adventures of Amina al Sarafi I am dnfing I think I got 120 pages in which is about 25% both these books like over 400 pages there was no point me getting through 400+ pages um if I knew I was gonna like it um this is a fantasy and I do struggle with fantasy I think it needs to be either young adult or if it's adult thanks to be like low fantasy or cozy fantasy and this one like I could just tell my brain was not comprehending things like I just knew I was just gonna have no idea what was going on and I was really interested in it I was interested in the storyline and I liked this had like motherhood aspects but I just knew I was gonna be confused and I just it wasn't fair to the book because fantasy lovers are gonna probably love this and then this one I'm also returning to the library this one I got less of the way through I made it 40 pages um but that's about 10% and I just knew again this one's not for me but I'm happy for all the romance lovers who love this book but yeah do you DNF and if you do at how far in do you call it quits

voice_to_text: Super excited. My new book, home is where my thing. Always been, my thing will always be my thing. Boom! Home is where the bodies are tells the story of three estranged siblings who must return home when their mother passes away, and it's their job to settle her state. Upon going through her belongings, they find a collection of home VHS tapes, including one marked summer 1999. When they pop the tape into the player on screen, their father appears covered in blood, telling their mother about a dead body they need to get rid of. And now the three siblings must decide, do they dig in and uncover the past, or did they take it to the grave with them just as their mother has? Homes where the bodies are is gripping, thrilling and twisty and is laced with 90s nostalgia. And you're gonna Wanna pick it up because it's probably the most beautifully written book my wife has ever written. My wife. Unlike her other ones, Joe. Plus, if you can't notice, right here, it's probably got the best damn book I've ever seen in my freaking life. So you need to go pick it up right now. That's how you do it. Thanks.

me coming for the original video or Jack or anything like that it's not me trying to start anything this is just there's a conversation that's going on particularly in the comment section on that video that I thought could do with some context and if you're interested in that that's what this video is about and yeah I finished writing three books in three months but like they're not finished they're not like I've written first drafts they're not complete they're not ready to be published I never said that they were and this is the question that a lot of people ask in the comments on the original video So two of them were written to be sent off to my publishers and I'm gonna be working on them for the rest of the year doing edits in all the different stages and stuff cause that's just how publishing works the first one I could have started it sooner but that's on me I'm a procrastinator the second one I thought I was gonna have till August to write it  turned outI had till April so that kind of crept up on me I feel like this was the point that was maybe missed in my original video that I posted because I used the I cry a lot but I am so productive sound because I was making a bandwidth for anything else like I was just rewatching episodes of Bluey in the evening cause that was all I had like the brain power for everything was going into these books and that's not normally how I would do it but it was how I had to in this case also like I write fast this is just how I write my brain works fast  I write fast like I'm I feel like it's a race between how quickly my brain is coming up with the ideas and building out the scene and how how quickly I can write what's happening that's just always how I’ve written that's what my process is like and it's different for everybody and everyone's gonna have a different approach in different way of doing things that works for them but this is also the way that I enjoy it the most and like I will sit and write like 10,000 words a day for a few days on the trot and then nothing for a little while I didn't necessarily have a luxury of that this time with these deadlines which is why I got a bit burned out but like I’ve sat down and written 50,000 words of fanfiction in a week several times cause like you know  Like I said that's just how I work and it's how I enjoy it and for me first drafts are fun it's where I'm enjoying the whole process and discovering characters I'm just having a good time with the writing then the editing is where the hard work comes in and that's why that takes a long time  for me voice_to_text: We are reading the books we already own. There is a pillow and a mug on top of these books on the floor. What is happening? If you're new here, I'm going through my bookshelf one book at a time, reading the ones I haven't read yet, and deciding what gets to stay and what's gotta go. Whence last we met, I had just finished an Ember in the ashes, and now I have finished A torch against the knight. Oh, my god. Let me tell you something about this. Okay? Let me. Let me just. Let me, let me. This book was a lot. There are moments in this book that are akin to, like, the Red Wedding in game of Thrones. There are things that happen at the end of this book that change the status quo for the character so much that you would think it was the end of the series, and yet, somehow, somehow, there are two more books. All I wanted for these characters for 450 pages was for them to find a save point. You know when you're playing a video game and you go into a room, there's a save point. You're like, woo, least I'm safe in here. I wanted them to find that room, and they never did. Everyone's in danger. Every single person in this book is in danger for the entire. Every page of it. And in this one, we actually get three POVs. We get a Helene POV I don't love Helene, but I feel for her. She also had my favorite line in an Ember in the ashes, so there's that. And in this book, bad things happen to everyone. But arguably the worst things happened to her. Like, my list of people who are not allowed to live to the end of this series has doubled just because of her storyline so far. I am obviously planning to keep these. Now, I got very lucky because one of you had the kindness and the audacity to send me books three and four in the mail. Though, whoever you are, you didn't put a note of any kind, so I. If you are the person who sent me these, thank you. That was so nice of you. So next up, I will be finishing this series at. Do you wanna check in when I finish Reaper at the Gates, or should I just read both of them and then check back in with you? What. What would you prefer? Do you wanna hear one combined meltdown or two separate meltdowns? By the way, I don't think I've ever showed you guys this. This is a pillow, and the pillowcase is a bookcase. I think my grandma made this for me. Maybe it was my mom. I can't remember. This is what I lay on when I read this in my giant teddy bear. Have I shown you my giant teddy bear? This is him. He's actually Taller than me. Unlike most of the men on the internet, when he says he's six feet tall, he's not lying. Feel like we got a little off track. So. Love these. Reading these next books. Thank you for your time.

these are my fast and mostly incoherent reviews of everything I read in April this is just twisted love but again except with even more obsession and stocking and on page moreture just in case you didn't get enough of that the first time around mark my words that Christian will be starting an in universe men's rights podcast at some point in the next 5 to 10 years this is the kind of book that you're going to wanna make all of the other people inside of your life read so that way you can have intellectual conversations with them over coffee this is lit fic it's about the 💀 penalty and rehabilitative justice and true crime ethics and just like what makes a good person and it has prose that is bright enough to light your way home like the North Star I absolutely love this it's my first and only five star book so far this year Abby Jimenez just loves inventing men that are tender and sweet enough to just torpedo your entire life your standards will never be the same after you read her books I also really appreciated the avoidantly attached traumatized female protagonist I won't say why you can draw your own conclusions that one sometimes things get weird in life and you just decide to read a dense nonfiction book about Scientology nothing has made me feel quite as cooked as this book in a very long time my reading experience was like force feeding a toddler vegetables but I'm glad I made it through I'm glad I read this because Scientology is absolutely insane it's bonkers and now I could spend several hours telling you exactly why if you love this I'm happy for you I am because I love the author I think that she is an absolute angel so I went into this truly with an open mind and an open heart but I cannot do anything other than shoot straight on this channel and unfortunately I just found this to be like a low res collage of a bunch of other popular young adult fantasies it just didn't work for me and I hate that but it's true these are short stories by the guy who invented Bojack Horseman and that is exactly the vibe that this collection gives off they are these weird and earnest portraits of love and loneliness and mental health that are written by and for mentally unstable people a good time I would say this book was so outlandish that it only ended up being a few steps away from Mafia man bought me and that's not exactly the vibe that I expected out of a Holly Jackson book but it did pull me out of a month long reading slump by the throat so I appreciate it for that it is impossible to capture how ambitious and interesting this book is in this wrap up so I'm not even going to try but dude just trust me if you want a really unique spin on a quest fantasy and on the typical hero’s journey that is presented to you in a way that is entirely fresh and has no business working as well as it does this is your guide it's one of the best fantasy stand alones that I think I've read in my entire life I strongly recommend I picked this up looking for a psychological thriller and what I got instead was kind of a lukewarm family drama things happen for sure they're intense but I did not care about a single character inside of this book but I mean I also did read it in one sitting in the middle of the night like a freak so props for that I guess this is a masterwork of 2011 literature it's got a college fight club it's got mısogyny it's got men and women that can never be friends I'd say that this is best read wearing hair feathers a tunic shirt and low rise jeans actually it's probably best not read at all this is a memoir about friendship and grief and growing up and going to college in the 1990s that as somebody who did not exist in the 1990s I still found to be very resonant I did think it was a little bit all over the place but also I mean it won a Pulitzer so goes to show what I know about these things maybe don't take me seriously this is a super tender sapphic young adult romance that felt like watching a classic romantic comedy it's got the banter it's got the slow mounting tension and yearning and it had the dopamine that I needed to get through this incredibly awful period of my life and I thank it for that

TO ENTER YOU MUST: ✅ Own the audio rights                        ✅ Be able to provide an audiobook cover                                                       ✅ Book is 160,000 words or less         ✅ Have a flexible schedule                  ❌ Must not already have a contract or be in talks with another narrator for this book                                            ❌ Must not already be an audiobook                                              ❌ Contain certain triggers (we can discuss privately)                                  #audiobooknarrator #indieauthor #writersoftiktok #booktok #fyp #shmiveaway #thankyou
voice_to_text: If you are an indie author and you would like to have your book turned into an audiobook, but you just don't have the money right now, please stick around till the end of this video. First and foremost, I would like to say a massive thank you to everyone who took part in Human Voices only. All of the talented narrators, all of the talented authors, and everyone who liked and shared and did all the things to spread the word. That support shows me that human connection is so important, and it's there. We don't want virtual voices and digital voices in our audiobooks. And you guys have shouted that from the rooftops, and I cannot tell you how good that makes me feel. And I've been trying to think of a way to really say thank you to this book community which has given me so much. And to say thank you, I'm gonna be making in an audiobook for an indie author for free. I will narrate it and edit it and bring it to life. All you would need to do is provide the audiobook cover, have a form on my profile. If you fill it out, you will automatically be entered. If you make a video supporting human voices only, and let me know, I will give you a second entry and then in a couple weeks will do the spinny wheel thing and I will pick a winner and that person will have Their book turned into an audiobook by me. There's a few little caveats. Um, I'll list them all below, such as how long the book is, there's certain triggers I'm not comfortable with, things like that. Um, but as long as all those things align, I'm really looking forward to making this project happen for somebody who wouldn't be able to make it happen otherwise. So I hope that this works out for everybody. Um, if you're interested, please head over to my profile and enter yourself in. And thank you again for supporting myself and my colleagues. Thank you.

voice_to_text: hi friends a little story time here this is this is a necklace I had made for myself around the time my mom had died my dad was declining and I had two really small little kids at home and it just felt like the end of my world I had this necklace made it's a it's a fortune cookie and on the fortune says no easy thing to bear the weight of sweetness and that line comes from a poem by a Chinese American poet named Lee Young Lee and I'm gonna introduce you to him today here's my necklace see I mean is it the cutest and I wore this necklace all the time during that period and I still wear it but I I don't take as much comfort from it anymore because I'm I've done a lot of healing but at the time it was like my my woobie it's like I got through my day because I had this no easy thing to bear the weight of sweetness Young Lee is a Chinese American poet and I'm gonna read you a poem where the that line came from if you don't know me I'm Alexandra Chan and the author of In the Garden Behind the Moon: A Memoir of Loss, Myth, and magic which comes out on May 28th This month is Asian American Native Hawaiian Pacific Islander Heritage Month that's a mouthful I'm just gonna call it AAPI I'm gonna introduce you periodically throughout the month you know some of the stuff that I've found most inspiring and and wonderful in the Asian diaspora this is from a book called rose or many beautiful poems in here and I should say too that I I haven't always been a lover of poetry not something that's come naturally to me but there are there are a few uh poets who have really cut through the fog and and stabbed me right in the heart and I'll be forever uh loyal to those poets because they make me feel something real this one is called the Weight of sweetness and it's short I'm just gonna read it to you though no easy thing to bear the weight of sweetness song wisdom sadness joy sweetness equals three of any of these gravities see a peach bend the branch and strain the stem until it snaps hold the peach try the weight sweetness and death so round and snug in your palm and so there is the weight of memory wind blown a rain soaked bowel shakes showering the man and the boy they shiver in delight and the father lifts from his son's cheek one green leaf fallen like a kiss the good boy hugs a bag of peaches his father has entrusted to him now he follows his father who carries a bag full in each arm see the look on the boy's face as his father moves faster and farther ahead while his own steps flag and his arms grow weak as he labors under the weight of peaches I think in the west we have a very simple understanding of the concept of sweet and sweetness and in Asian culture is a much more multifaceted many layered textured phenomenon and I just wanna come back to that one line song wisdom sadness joy sweetness equals three of any of these gravities if you've got song wisdom and sadness You’ve got sweetness you've got wisdom sadness and joy? sweetness  joy wisdom song? sweetness  anyway there is something unbearably painful about that time in my life and also unbearably sweet I hope I've captured some of that in my book which is coming out on May 28th add it to your Goodreads get your pre order in I can't wait to share it with the world

voice_to_text: what is the one question that nobody on Booktok ever wants to be asked? how big is your TBR? not only how big is it but what does it say about you? if your TBR is under 10 books this isn't a TBR you're either very new to Booktok or you have the iron will of a nun if your TBR is 20 to 40 books I think that's a normal healthy TBR it's enough books to be able to browse your next read but not so many that the sight of it makes you start to physically sweat if your TBR is 50 to 100 books look it's still manageable but you probably got a growing sense of unease that this is an issue you need to address unless you're an absolute speed reading demon you're gonna need to start getting involved in some book buying bans pretty soon if your TBR is 100 to 300 books well you've been here for a while haven't you? your bookshelves are starting to give your local library a run for their money it's time to cross the road every time you see a bookshop and I think you may need external help if your TBR is over 500 books then actually you can relax your TBR is now so large that realistically you're never going to get on top of it so it's time to set yourself up as an independent bookshop and pretend this was just your business plan all along it's confession time booktok tell me how big your TBR is and what you're planning to do about it

voice_to_text: So Sierra Leone is declaring an emergency after addicts are digging up graves to get high on a drug made from human bones. So for those of you don't know, Sierra Leone is on the west coast of Africa, and they are currently facing an epidemic where there's a drug called Kush that being used all over and manufactured partly by using human bone. This is causing people to come rob graves and steal the bones of buried people. Apparently the drug is pretty cheap to manufacture, just requires one specific ingredient that requires people to steal bones from old cemeteries, in which case the government has actually had to beef up security at cemeteries to stop this problem. And this drug creates sort of a hypnotic high, as ones would describe. They said this drugs first started being produced around six years ago in their country. And the epidemic of users and the increase in grave robberies has skyrocketed since. The doctors are also seeing an increase of around 4,000% of deaths due to organ failures, which is a direct result of this drug use.

voice_to_text: I feel like being an only child played such a big role in my aroace journey or honestly just not having any older siblings so this will probably also apply to people that only have younger siblings but I feel like for people that have older siblings so much of what you learn about growing up and sex and romance and feelings and all of those things are through your older siblings you start to form an opinion on those things when you see them experiencing it and so as an only child I never saw that I didn't even know that those were things I was supposed to be feeling it wasn't until halfway through high school when I gained friends that were very open about those feelings that I realized they even existed outside of movies and I definitely think that if I had older figures in my life whether they're siblings or somebody else I would have figured that out a lot sooner so let me know if you're older siblings or lack there of influenced your aroace journey

So I'm doing a rewatch of Bridgerton to prepare for the new season, and I just generally read a lot of romance novels. Um, so I just wanna share my potentially unpopular opinion, which is that romance needs more bitches. Like, the reason that season 2 of Bridgerton, to me, is so vastly superior to season 1 is because the female main character is, like, not a perfect person. Like, she's kind of antagonistic and complicated, and she's being somewhat deceitful to her younger sister, and, like, just generally, she's not a perfect person. And I feel like in general, but especially in mainstream romance, the female characters are held to such a high standard of likeability and morally consistent behavior that, first of all, the male characters are never held to. Like, half the time the male love interests are, like, borderline emotionally abusive with how avoidant and withholding they are, and it's treated as sexy. I also just kind of find it really tiring to constantly be reading about these women who are perfect moral beings who are arriving into these relationships almost as a blank slate. In general, my favorite books in any genre are ones that follow somewhat complicated or otherwise problematic female main characters. And not just because it's interesting, but also it feels more true to life. Like, women are human and humans are imperfect, but I feel like women so rarely get to do that in romance without being completely destroyed anyway. We need more black cat golden retriever love stories. So if you have any really good romance novels or ROM coms, uh, starring a bitch, uh, drop them in the comments.

voice_to_text: I will never forgive The Princess Bride for how it eviscerated my concept of reality when I was 13 years old and somebody told me that my favorite movie was actually based on a book you have no idea how quickly I went and grabbed it and my copy used to say The Princess Bride by S Morganstetn on the cover because the world likes to destroy my faith  actually lies I just looked it up it's this one but you know what happened when I saw this? I saw this man's name underneath it and I went who the 🦆 is William Goldman my nemesis that's who you see William Goldman’s entire stick when he wrote this book is that he is writing the adaptation of the story that used to be read to him when he was a little kid he's essentially this kid in the Princess Bride movie and he sells to you 100% in a author's note that he is not the author of the original Princess Bride he is giving you the abridged version of the original s Morgan Stern book and me as a young child who did not want no adaptation I wanted the original I wanted the entire chapter where a princess was loading nothing but hats into a suitcase Verbatim  I go, “I don't want this William Goldman nonsense!” “I want the original!” q a three year search in my refusal to read a book for that long because I think it's fake and then it turns out to be one of my favorite parody books of all time and honestly one of my favorite reads and I'm really annoyed that it took me that long and you know what William Goldman you could have just been straightforward with me

voice_to_text: no but this is my favourite act of micro feminism so I teach a class at a university and the other day I'm walking on campus going back to my car after class so I'm on the sidewalk on the correct side of the sidewalk only taking up my one little lane and I'm walking to the car and sure enough there's a group of eight young men walking towards me taking up the entire sidewalk none of them are on their phones talking to each other but they're all looking forward and they just keep walking forward nobody moves over they are taking up the entire sidewalk and I just kept walking in my lane and I literally walked into one of them anyways I'm recovering people pleaser in my early 20s I met with a licensed counselor anyway she's the one who told me to pay attention when I'm walking on sidewalks because men will rarely yield women if they're walking in a group and walking opposite directions they'll just expect you to move out of the way and so the micro feminist thing to do is to just stay in your lane and let them run into you and don't apologize because they're not following the rules of the sidewalk the eightish years since I've gotten that advice is still shocking to me how often this happens and I'm sure there will be people in my comments who are like oh no it's just you but if you're a woman let me know if you've experienced this before too

Booktok Drama- Do you think book stores should charge a fee when authors are speaking for free? #booktok #booktokdrama #writertok #books
voice_to_text: I am mildly fighting with some booksellers over the other app threads because I put up this post where I recount experience I had recently where I was invited by the bookstore to speak on a panel for a different author's book. And this was last minute, about two weeks before the event. I got added to the panel and I find out that the store is charging a five dollar cover charge. Five dollars is not being put towards the purchase of a book, anything like that. There were no snack served, no drink served. This was just an overhead fee. And I am uncomfortable with that because I am donating my time. I'm traveling there, I'm paying for gas, I'm paying for parking. I'm donating about two hours of time. And some books are like, oh, but you get exposure and you get the cost of your royalties on the book. I make $2 per hardcover book. So if I sell five books, which would be pretty decent for a panel like this, that's $10. The bookstore makes $8 off of each of my hardcover books. And I get it, you don't want people bringing outside books. So then maybe make the cost of the book the ticket for entry. Or maybe make the $5 to be applied to any book in the store as to ask people to pay for your overhead. When the authors are donating their time, it doesn't sit right. Because, yes, bookstores are Struggling, but so are authors. To stay afloat, authors give up all the time, and I think our time needs to be just as valued. So what do you think? Should book stores charge an overhead fee when they are inviting authors in to speak for free?

so people always ask me if I've seen the show The Bear I have not I don't watch chef shows whether they're competitions dramas comedies I'm just not interested ever since the show came out though I've gotten hundreds of messages whether through email or on Instagram some from people I know some from people I don't know but people who have read my book and said oh my god I saw the did you write for it did they use some of your book um have you seen it do do you know that there's um a lot of your story in it but um I'm certainly Bear curious I've heard that it's great right and so every time I see an article that's written about it um I definitely read it but I just can't quite bring myself to watch it but in 2019 I wrote my first memoir called burn the place it was long listed for the National Book Award won some local prizes like the Midlands Author Prize which was um just very amazing and I had no expectations for any of that stuff when I was writing it and I would really wasn't thinking about my audience of course I knew it would be some food people but more so than a book about cooking this is a story of you know determination and addiction queerness um family loss grief just everything you know it's um a story of my life what I could do is read about a minute a day and see what you guys think um if you have seen the bear maybe you will see some of the correlations uh hopefully you'll be compelled to go buy it or if you know somebody who might have some sort of resonance with it maybe you'll buy it and give it to them as a gift I will start here

voice_to_text: I generally do not like it when books have characters on the covers. My favourite style at the moment is something like this, but let's get into some exceptions to that rule. First up, and I've talked about these before, villains and virtues. This is a trilogy and the art style is absolutely incredible, both inside and on the extra bonus picture you get in the last book, and it fits the characters so, so well. I don't think I've ever seen artwork and just been like, that is exactly who was in my head. This is a fantasy fairytale romcom. Grumpy Sunshine, enemies to lovers. It is absolutely incredible. I have a whole video all about them, but the artwork, stunning. Next up, anything by FT. Lukens. I don't know how they do it, but every single cover is so incredible. So well fitted to the characters and just so amazingly done with the scene that they choose to depict. All of these ones I'm holding are M M romances. They are like you've stepped into a fairy tale. Absolutely incredible, heartwarming, standalone happily ever after. Would definitely recommend. Next up, and a much newer find of mine, although it is not a new book, is the fairly edition of silver in the bone. And the reason that I love this one so much is because the characters look for the age they are in the book. I see so much fan art of characters are like 17 18 As these guys are. And they look like they're in their mid twenties or 30s in the fan art. And this, they look like teenagers in the end paper art as well, and I absolutely love it. This is a YA urban fantasy based in authorian legend. I have a video about this if you do wanna learn a bit more. The last one and the one that surprised me the most is forged in magic by Jenna Wolfhard. And I was surprised because this is such a typical romancy cover. They look, you know, very intimate, very cozy. Um. And it's one of the more realistic art styles, but I just think it works so well. The colouring is amazing, and the rest of our books have the same kind of style on them. I just don't have them with me, even though I wish I had them with me. Someone who doesn't like character covers. There are actually more, and I might make another video with them. But those ones that stuck out to me when I was thinking about character covers that I actually like.

voice_to_text: what makes you want to read a book? what are the things that stand out to you that's gonna make you pick it up from the library or purchase it yourself I'm pretty simple I look for three things I look for an interesting cover really good artwork I look for a good blurb like and description inside the sleeve and if it's in my genre my preferred genre I tend to avoid deep dive reviews I I just don't want to be influenced by somebody else their take on a character their their take on the theme or a narrative like I will seek out that review after I'm done to see if we line up I will seek out such review to see if I miss something if I didn't understand something maybe somebody else picked it up and it's going to kinda like give me more introspection does that make sense and this is very petty and specific to me um I see anybody holding ACOTAR immediate skip I also don't like reviews that show the book only like the spine or the back of it um show me the cover you have three seconds to do it otherwise I'm skipping this is becoming a new thing that I noticed but if you are advertising your book and you put like tropes around it to show what's in it not reading that. allow me to figure out the tropes because if you don't deliver on those tropes your book is gonna get knocked down a couple stars so I I I avoid those books cause I don't wanna be unchariable this one may sound a bit strange and controversial but just bear with me for a second um any book that in the beginning lists all the triggers like sensitive subjects I appreciate that it's there it should be there I personally skip that page I don't read it I don't know if this makes any sense but like for me it's much easier to read sensitive subject material problematic material versus seing it on screen I can't explain it that's how my brain functions when I'm trying to get it I don't like to be preemptively told what this book is about these are all the triggers these are all the tropes like I will figure that out for myself and make up my own mind and no I'm not saying that those things should not be there they should and you as a reader have a choice to skip that those stupid cartoon cover covers of romances that are becoming a thing now absolutely not immediate turn off I don't care how good your story is that's an immediate turn off I'm not picking up your book so yeah I I'm pretty simple uh good artwork good cover will always get me description inside a sleeve that's not too like giving giving away and preferably my genre those three things I will read your book

video_description: Booktok Writers- Be prepared to change your book title if you go into traditional publishing. #booktok #writertok #booktitle #writingabook
voice_to_text: If you are going into traditional publishing, you're just gonna have to be prepared to let your title go. There are forces at work in the marketing department that you don't have access to. I have a new book. It's another young adult horror novel. And we were going back on titles forever because sales and marketing would say it needs to be a short title. Long titles aren't selling anymore. So needs to be 2, 3 words Max. No, you can't use girls in the titles. We noticed that books with the word girls in the titles aren't selling as much as they were before. Leah, it's a true generic. Cause then it won't have any search engine optimization. And we're just going back and forth on all of these titles. So do not get your heart set on the title that is on your current manuscript, because once it gets sold to traditional publishing, there are a lot more forces at play based on what they think will sell the book, not on what made most accurately represent the content of your book. They are selling a product, and what are consumers going to be attracted to? What is going to look good in conjunction with the art on the cover, and what is going to make a consumer want to pick it up right now in this current market. And we just don't have access to that information. So you've got to be flexible and just know That titles are going to happen

voice_to_text: the Greek underworld  and Tartarus are actually  different places Tartarus is not  in the underworld  and Hades doesn't  actually rule over Tartarus Hades rules over the underworld which consists of elysium which is where the good people go When they die  the fields of asphodel which where the  meh people go when they die and then the  fields of punishment  Which is where the bad people go when they die  Tartarus isn't a place  people go when they die it's basically the  gods’ supermax prison Hades doesn't put  people in Tartarus it's mostly Zeus who does that and Zeus is the one that  decides their punishment and for those of you who  don't believe that Tartarus  isn't in the underworld look at all the people Zeus  has put in Tartarus  he doesn't wait for them to die he just sends them to Tartarus  famous prisoners of Tartarus include  Kronos and the other titans  Tantalus Sisyphus and even sometimes Prometheus is considered  to have his punishment being in Tartarus  in a lot of modern tellings of Greek mythology you can get to Tartarus   through the underworld but I think it's still important to know  that it's not part of the underworld Tartarus is a prison for the enemies of the gods and those who the gods think deserve extra punishment it is adjacent to the realm of hades  but is not in the realm of hades

voice_to_text: Blowing $10,000 a year is only $27 of miscellaneous spending every single day. Now I know you've probably heard this stat before. It can be shocking and also frustrating but I do think that there is an important lesson to take here. But first, I'm Paige. I'm the founder of Overcoming Overspending. I help you stop impulse shopping and overspending and this is your daily deinfluencing video. Every single day I drop a video that's either going to deinfluence you help you form healthier consumption habits or just get a little better with your money. So if you need more content like that make sure to interact with this video so that every single day you can get a little dose of deinfluencing. I think what triggers a lot of people around this stat is that it really ties closely into the narrative that a lot of us have been fed that you know if you just give up your daily latte or if you give up appetizers at the restaurant that that will be the make or break difference between you being able to retire or being able to buy a home one day. And of course I've never subscribed to that because when you do the math the math just obviously doesn't math. But I will say I have a community of hundreds of women who all struggle with their spending and consumption habits and from what I see it's not the big expenses that happen once in a while that throw them off most… it's just the daily miscellaneous spending that's happening on a daily or a weekly basis. So it really can turn into a death by a thousand cuts situation and it's like the saying goes small leaks can sink a great ship. When it comes to our spending we tend to be in an all or nothing mindset where we say okay well if making these changes isn't going to do the big things for me if it's not gonna help me buy a home or if it's not gonna help me retire one day then I'm just gonna do what I want and spend what I want. And so no, the $27 a day probably won't be the difference between you being able to retire or buy a home one day but it could be the difference between you actually having some cushion in your checking account and not constantly overdrafting it and paying those really expensive overdraft fees. It could be the difference between you being able to take a weekend trip away one time a year or being able to pay off that pesky retail credit card that's just hanging over your head that you never really seem to have the money to pay. It could be the difference between you not being completely stressed and spiraling out of control when your dog needs surgery or when something breaks down in your car that you need to repair. So no these things aren't buying a home or building a seven-figure retirement portfolio but they are the tiny little things the tiny little moments in your financial journey that when you're not prepared for them cause the most stress and the most angst and are the biggest hit to your financial confidence and the things that when you actually are prepared for them they can actually boost your financial morale more than you think that they will.  Now, this isn't to say that you have to cut out all of your miscellaneous spending but I think you will be surprised when you can just focus on one area of your consumption and really tweaking that and reigning that in what a huge difference it just makes overall. So yes, maybe it is the coffee if that's something that's big for you. But it could be something else. Maybe it's books. You stop buying books that you just never read and you say I'm not gonna buy a new book until I read all the ones that I have. Or maybe it's skincare or perfume. I'm not gonna buy anything more there until I use what I have. Maybe you just make a commitment to stop adding like the small random tchotchke’s and trinkets into your cart when you're standing in the checkout line at Old Navy or Homegoods. Don’t tell yourself it doesn't make a difference. Don’t tell yourself it doesn't matter. Because it does. Even if it doesn't allow you to do the big things and reach the big milestones it'll help you reach those smaller ones which again boost your financial morale and confidence more than you think that it will. If you're needing help with your spending or consumption habits I'm here for you. Make sure that you give my page a follow. Head to my bio and you can start listening to and binging my podcast which is called the Money Love Podcast.  You can also sign up for my free master class called Why you Impulse Shop and How to Stop. It’s a great free resource to get you started. Alright I love y'all. I will see you in tomorrow's video.

voice_to_text: I truly don't think that book talk as a collective unit, understands just how much power you have over the publishing industry right now. I self published this book two years ago. Two full ass years ago, and it did okay. It didn't, you know, have a ton of sales or really blow up. Signed with my agent, who was pitching my adult book. Um, she offered to pitch this around a little bit two years ago, um, to foreign publishers, to audiobook publishers. And nothing. Crickets. No one was interested. But three weeks ago, Book Talk as a whole decided that you guys liked this book, that you wanted to read it and share it. And there were no big agents that were involved in this. There were no publishing houses, no nothing. You guys just decided you liked my book and made it viral, and within five days, we had an audio deal. You guys don't know the power that you have right now. Major publishers are quaking in their goddamn boots trying to figure out how the hell this book talk thing works and how to blow up the authors that they sign. But they don't know the trick. There is no trick. There is no way to harness the power of book talk. The readers are the ones who decide what they like and what becomes popular. And that is. That's crazy. It's like in the iconic 2000 movie Stick it, where the gymnast choose who They want to win each event, which is completely unrealistic, obviously, but that's what's happening right now. Publishing is this massive Dinosaur of an industry, and the readers are disrupting that industry in real time. You have no idea what that does for smaller authors like myself, who don't have a lot of sales to our name. It completely changes the game. Seriously, the power is in book talks hands. It's in the readers hands. So don't waste it.

voice_to_text: So one of the ways that asexual insecurity shows up in my life is in believing that I am not going to be good enough. I harbor a fear that no matter what I bring to the table in a relationship in my life, it is not going to be good enough, that it will not measure up to what an equally situated aloe person would bring to the table. That, of course, stems from the messages we receive all the time about the illegitimacy and inadequacy of asexuality, which come from Allenormative ideas and compulsory sexuality. We have to remember that our sexual orientation isn't everything we are, and that when we are feeling that insecurity about being not enough, we have to think about all the things we are, all the things we bring to the table, all the ways we are unique and special and worthy.

voice_to_text: Which aesthetic and tools. As somebody who adores the which aesthetic and lives in it practically, I have to make something very clear. The witchy aesthetic, whether it's in your tools or your clothing, doesn't inherently affect your craft and improve the quality. We all want the fancy tools. We all want the fancy besons, the fancy cauldrons, but the problem is we can't always afford it. Historically, when it comes to the tools the practitioners have used in the past, they used what they had. They didn't have fancy shops that they could go to and get the most expensive cauldron. They had to make do or they had to make the items themselves. And we can learn something from that. If you want to get fancy tools, that is completely fine and you should not be judged for doing that. But at the same token, people shouldn't be judged for using what's available to them because they have a very tight budget, whether it's custom made or is bought from a supermarket. The quality doesn't inherently change when it comes to how we use them in our practice and how effective they are. For example, instead of a fancy bessemble broom, I have a bundle of twigs that my mother bought me from marks and Spencer's. Blesser. And before you go, marks and Spencer's is expensive. These were on a ￡50 yellow label, and they work. They are kind of falling apart a little bit, though, but I'm On a budget? If they do the job, they do the job. And I'm gonna use them just as much as instead of a fancy cauldron, you can use pots and pans. If you're on a budget, do not put pressure on yourself to buy the most expensive tools out there. Use what you have. Which brings me to the witchy aesthetic. Just because I adhered to the witchy aesthetic, it does not make me a better or worse practitioner than somebody else who has a different style. Witchy aesthetic is something that flows in and out of fashion every couple of years. And while I really like it, a lot of people don't. And not every practitioner needs to adhere to that. Style is not a requirement. You could do your spell work in a comfy, oversized T-shirt and a pair of leggings for all I care. I do. The spell I'm doing doesn't require very specific things in terms of what I'm wearing and ritualistic clothes. I'm gonna wear the comfiest clothes imaginable, thank you very much. Especially if I'm gonna be sitting there for hours. In conclusion, style does not inherently have a factor to play in the quality of the work that you produce in your practice. It is just an aesthetic. And whether you would hear to it or not, if you're practicing witchcraft, you're a witch. Period.

voice_to_text: as a late World Book Day question I'm curious which books have influenced your life the most not necessarily your favourite books but if they crossover that's absolutely fine for me there are three there's The Dandelion Years by Erica James I reckon if I'd read this a bit later I would have chosen this as a university path instead I chose English literature which is still you know related but I think book restoration and restoring old books and book binding and all that sort of things is so interesting and I wish I'd kind of pursued it a bit more second is expectation by Anna Hope I read this in my third year of Uni when I'd stopped kind of reading and it was the first book that I'd sat down and read and enjoyed for a long time and so it made me read again which started me book blogging and also made me want to pursue a career in book publishing the final book is Am I Normal yet by Holly Bourne I read it for an essay about feminism and mental health posted about it on Tumblr and through Tumblr I started talking to Sam who's my partner so they are three books that have really influenced my life and I'd be interested to hear yours

voice_to_text: respectfully I invite you to recognize why telling people they read too much or too fast is rooted in white patriarchy in childhood we were rewarded for reading which was considered “good” or “ladylike” behavior we read constantly because we were raised in a world that still believes that unheard and unseen is better our parents praised us our teachers and librarians rewarded us Pizza Hut fed us we connected with characters on an emotional level we trained our brains to keep track of characters and settings we stayed at home after school and on weekends because who needs to go out when you can stay safe at home surrounded by hundreds of friends if you want to read slow by all means read slowly but telling the world that reading fast or reading a lot is a bad thing why does it bother you?! I saw a young man on social media a couple of weeks ago insisting that reading too many books denied the purpose of literature he said that people are better off reading one book slowly and in depth rather than reading tens or hundreds of books a year I weep for his loneliness if my analytics are any measure 85% of book related social media accounts are curated by women or female presenting readers when someone says “people who read a lot of books aren't reading thoughtfully or with intention,” they mean “I will regulate your time (and body).” when someone says “reading slowly is the only way to sink deep into form and meaning,” they mean “over consumption of pleasurable activities signals promiscuity.” when someone says “reading too many books a year means a lack of recall and understanding,” they mean “reading a wide variety of multicultural authors undermines the influence of the Western canon.” when someone says “audiobooks don't count as reading,” they mean “mundane activities require your full attention and should not be used as opportunities for education or entertainment.” notice how many of the same people mock readers who annotate their books if we read too much we're “book sluts” if we annotate and take notes we're “obsessed” if you think I'm reading too much into it ask yourself why those people aren't saying the same thing about the other arts no one mocks strangers for going to art museums or concerts why is it okay to listen to music while you drive or fold laundry or cook but not listen to an audiobook?! it's because information is power and a well informed populace challenges the status quo George R R Martin said “a reader lives a thousand times before he dies,  the man who never reads lives only once.” I want to live them all and none of us whether we read fast or slow will ever be able to make up for the voices lost to the white male establishment who dominated media and publishing for, like, ever wanting to control what or how much a person reads is about wanting to have dominion over them and it's a slippery slope to book banning and book burning and shutting libraries no one is better at selecting the quality or the quantity of what we read than ourselves mind your own business

Going to start off the new year breaking down everything I did to increase my net worth by $400,000 in about five years. Welcome, and here we go. #FinancialFreedom, #PersonalFinances #InvestingExplained #PersonalFinanceStories #FinanceStories #MoneyDiaries #NetWorthUpdate #HowMuchISpend
voice_to_text: I'm 32 years old with a 300,000 dollar net worth and that maybe a lot to some people and very little to other people but to me I'm really proud of it because just a couple years ago back in 2019 I had a negative 70,000 dollar net worth and I had no idea what I was doing with my money I was stressed out all the time I couldn't handle a 500 dollar emergency lived paycheck to paycheck part of that is because I spent so much of my life believing I was just bad with money and that the only solution for me to get good with money wasn't for me to learn and educate myself it was me to find somebody to do it for me mostly I was thinking in the aspect of like oh you date somebody you get married and then they do the money stuff because I can't do the money stuff cause I'm bad with money but when we do that like we're giving away our power over one of the most valuable assets we have in life money is related to literally everything that we do our security our ability believe a job ability to stay in our apartment believing in this idea that I couldn't do it it put me in some really bad situations in my twenties where I'd have to live with abusive exes because I couldn't leave I didn't have the money to go I'd have panic attacks from not knowing how I was gonna pay rent I went $15,000 into credit card debt for an ex and eventually back in 2018 2019 I finally had this moment where I was like okay we can't keep doing this we can't keep doing this thing over and over again because clearly it's not working and so I started educating myself I started learning where my money was going I started focusing on increasing my income and here we are now so I increase my net worth by over $400,000 in five years uh and I'm really proud of that but what I what this video is for is I'm gonna do a series of essentially what my journey was um so if that's something that you're into uh hop on and enjoy the ride

voice_to_text: What advice would you give your younger self? Enjoy life as much as you can. Sometimes we make things too complicated when we are young. Too much pressure. When you're a student, for instance, money, exams, job prospects. When you reach 50, you realise that things were not that complicated and the pressure was unnecessary. I completely understand and I sympathize with the pressure that the younger generation is going through and feels, cause it's obvious. But I just think that later on in life she perhaps you become aware of that what really matters the most is, you know, what's around you, your family, what you do with them. Perhaps you're less demanding on the bigger picture. And that fear of failure, how does one go about fighting that fear? I mean, failure is, you know, it depends to, um, the type of standards you set to yourself. The only standard that we should set up to ourselves is to be happy in our life. Content. That's the No. 1 standard that we should stick up to. Are you happy? Yeah, I am. Very much.
