All of your favorite artists steal from other artists. We see this in every art medium by every iconic artist. If we see this so often, why is there such a negative connotation of stealing? Pablo Picasso once said, good artists copy, great artists steal. So there is a difference between copying and stealing. When these iconic artists steal, they work like collage artists, taking art pieces that inspire them and creating something new. Which is different from taking that inspiration and copying or tracing it inch by inch. Your art can be inspired, but it starts crossing the line when your art heavily relies on its origin. My goal with creating this is to encourage you not to copy, but instead steal like an artist. Take something you are inspired by and expand further to the point that it is something new. The reality is, art has existed since 30,000 BP. So artist putting this pressure to make something that's never been done before is just wasted energy and is creating an insane amount of imposter syndrome. The Isaac Newton once said, if I had seen further, it's by standing on the shoulders of giants. And that was after he stolen that quote from John of Salisbury.
video_description: Here is the idea around art that doesn’t get talked about. I believe that art is a shared culture. We as artists need to embrace the idea of grabbing references and inspiration when we are looking to create art. It gives us a better perspective on what we are sculpting together. Whether you are in film, animation, painting, or any other art medium this information all applies. Learning from the successes of others is how we grow and succeed 🤍 When I was in film school I saw this video called “Everything is a Remake” focusing on this very idea. It gave me a whole new outlook on creating art. If you haven’t seen it I really suggest that you do!  - #motiongraphics #animation #vfx #tutorial #animationbreakdown #graphic #design #illustration #2danimation #art #aftereffects #adobe #mograph #3danimation #animationreels #vfxeditor #motiondesigner #film #cinematography #director #series #lighting #directing #photography #pablopicasso #quentintarantino

48 laws of power. That's what we're doing today. It's a great book, and Chaz recommended this. It's written by, I think, Robert Green. And we're gonna take the 5 key points, and then we're gonna discuss it. Point one. This is so significant. Never outshine the master. The most important part of your life as an assistant is to help your boss shine. This rule advises you that you must never do better or get more credit than the person that you serve. Number 2. I love this one, and I'm sure people have heard this before, but so true. Keep your friends close and your enemies closer. This law tells us to keep our people with us who love us, but also to keep a close eye on those who don't. This can help us stay ahead of their moves and prevent them from causing us harm. Number 3. Make the illusion of your power greater than the reality. People will always follow what they see and not what they truly think. This law advises you to project greater power and control than you actually have. Number 4. Oh, I love this. Practice this my whole life. Always say less than necessary. This law preaches that we should speak only when required and let people assume at what you might mean, keeping them curious. I've never heard this before. It says, use selective honesty. Selective honesty and generosity to disarm your victim. People trust those who seem honest. And generous. This law advises that you use this image to get them to lower their guard and gain an advantage over them.

impression after reading the book was mostly that I am too dumb to understand the three body problem now to be clear the problem is 100% on my end this thing has hundreds of thousands of ratings on Amazon or on Goodreads everyone loves The Three Body Problem it has sold millions of copies and it is comforting to know that at least this many people smarter than me exist so the title the Three Body Problem refers to a famously difficult problem in physics if I was to try to boil it down to the simplest terms possible I would say that basically in physics and classical mechanics the 3 body problem is the problem of taking the initial positions and velocities or momentum of 3 point masses and solving further subsequent motion according to Newton’s law of motion and Newton’s law of universal gravitation so the 3 body problem is a special case of the n-body problem where unlike 2 body problems no general closed form solutions exist as resulting dynamic system as chaotic for most Yo, imagine being a parent whose adult children cut all ties to you. They don't even speak to you anymore. They don't call you on your birthday. They don't plan anything for mothers or Father's Day. They never even update you on your grandchildren's milestones, refuse to come to your bedside when you're chronically ill. Never visit you in the nursing home. I mean, if they saw you in line at Starbucks, they probably sighed at you for a minute and then pretend like they didn't even know you. All because you failed so fantastically, so monumentally at your job. Your one job, as the loving, supportive presence in their lives that your children would rather dethrone you from quite arguably one of the most irreplaceable positions you could ever hold in another human being's life. Voluntarily orphaning themselves, then spend one more millisecond of their time on Betty White's Green Earth, drowning themselves in your emotional immaturity. Couldn't be me.

voice_to_text: this book should be called Watch ⚪️ness Work cause that's what the hell it is hello loves and welcome to another episode of Cash It or Trash It I'm your host Sierra T. I have a couple of minutes or so to describe you a synopsis of a book I've read recently and I let you know whether or not you should cash it or trash it and this week we are talking about Yellow Face by RF Kuang I've seen all of the discourse on TikTok um let's get into it so at the top of this book we meet Athena Lou and Juniper Hayward or June um and they are frenemies they both went to Yale together as aspiring authors and they both applied to the same writing programs things like that at the top of this book we find out that Athena Lou is the literary darling of the industry at this point I mean she's got the girls sick right hit after hit after hit you know and all the other girls are shaking crying screaming throwing up and one of those girls that shaking crying and screaming and throwing up is Juniper Hayward who I think is the most ultimate hater in a book I've ever read in my life on top of being a racist but we'll get there so one night Athena and June are kicking it at Athena’s crib and Athena chokes and dies on some pancakes it's a hell of a way to die and June is there to see the whole thing she does try to resuscitate her but she don't really know what she's doing anyway Athena dies one thing leads to another and June ends up stealing one of Athena’s manuscripts for a book called The Last Front and this book becomes a national bestseller but not without its pros and cons and without people calling her out this book is tricky y'all this book is tricky because we Learned through the book that Juniper is a disgusting person she's narcissist she's racist she can hardly take any accountability and funny enough which I don't find a lot of people mentioning this in their reviews she is surrounded by people who consistently and continuously support her ideology oh child let's talk about it let's talk about it Eden Books is the company that publishes not only Athena’s work but also June’s June’s team I find is also as just as disgusting if not more which to me is also a sickening part when you think about how this is like RF  Kuang’s like angry angry letter to the publishing industry these same people that are on June’s team at almost at every moment they go out of their way to try to help her even when even when it is confirmed and factually checked that she stole the manuscript y'all I mean this book should be called Watch ⚪️ness Work cause that's what the hell it is oh my god but there's also other parts of this that I think are tricky too and I think RF Kuang did a very interesting point with this I think if you're not someone who isn't necessarily careful about paying attention to ⚪️ supremacy and ⚪️ privilege and ⚪️ ideology and ⚪️ dog whistles you could find yourself agreeing with certain points or Povs that June presents as inner monologue in this book okay the other funny part about this is that Athena she's not that great of a person either and we Learned that in flashbacks and you know prior stories in situations that June had with Athena right so also it's like it's also it's giving us a morally gray kind of area because you're like oh 💩 okay Granted she did steal from Athena and Athena’s not a great person but that don't make that right and that don't make that right like I see why all of the reviews have been like split down the middle but I thought oh my god this is very very interesting take on the publishing industry and how we constantly hear even on book talk alone have a conversation about you know whether ⚪️ people should be writing characters of color can they represent them right and I think I mean if I'm looking at this the answer the answer is no man this book is so goddamn good y'all you gotta read it there's gonna be moments in here where you're gonna be like Oh I mean cause it's like unbelievably racist oh my god y'all it's so fucking good you should cash it

This Book Is A Cheat Code To Life
voice_to_text: This book was actually banned in US prisons, and I actually read it when I was a teenager. It's the 48 laws of power by the big homie, Robert Green. And I met him a few times. I got interviews with me and him on my YouTube page. And it was banned in prison because, allegedly, it has brutal manipulation tactics or instructions. The reason is one of my favorite books. Not because I want to manipulate people. I just want to know how not to get manipulated. There's also things that you did I feel anyone can use. Like, for example, Law Number 10, avoid unhappy and Unlucky People. It's contagious, man. Life falling apart. And they have all this bad stuff going around and their life. That stuff can seep into your life. What happens if they start bringing their problems and all their issues into your life? What do you think you're gonna start seeing everywhere? Right? Same thing. I look at this book as it's a cheat code to life. It had a really positive impact on me and my life, and I think you should read it.
